We have the ability to ensure that our country continues to stay involved with programs that will help these women to climb out of the desperate situations they find themselves in. It is about education programs, it is about health and nutrition programs, and it is about family planning. It is about breaking down barriers in so many countries where women are never given the opportunity to break the poverty cycle. In short, their basic human rights are ignored.

However, not all is doom and gloom. As women we have a lot to celebrate todayâthe achievements and sacrifices of so many in the past that have given us what we have today. But I say to my colleagues in the House today that we must continue to fight for the rights of all women around the globe; we must never forget that the struggles we have been through are only just beginning for so many others. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: âInternational Women's Day offers women around the world the opportunity to reflect on progress in the area of women's rights and to demand the removal of barriers that stop all women from being able to fully participate in our society. As the member for Ballarat, it affords me the opportunity to reflect on the many issues faced by the women I come across in my day-to-day working life. I am constantly amazed at the resilience and courage of ordinary women who achieve extraordinary things despite the barriers that are still presented to themâbarriers that, in my area, centre on health and employment.

speech.para: Women are the biggest users of Medicare. In the crucial child-bearing and child-rearing years between 20 and 45, women use twice as many Medicare services as men. In my electorate, there are simply not enough doctors to adequately service the population. The shortage of doctors, coupled with the reduction of access to bulk-billing, has the potential to compromise the health of women in my electorate. I do not think it is too much to ask that women in my electorate have access to affordable and accessible health care, yet the government has shown itself incapable of any action.

The disturbing revelations of the past week about alleged sexual assaults by rugby league players in New South Wales and Victoria have highlighted a serious problem in the attitude of some men towards women in our society. But even more disturbing is that the focus of much of the commentary in the media and by sporting bodies has been on the reputation of rugby and its players. Where are our sporting heroes talking about the impact on women of such alleged assaults?

In my community, in the past eight months alone the Ballarat Centre Against Sexual Assault had 188 new referrals of women accessing their counselling and advocacy services. There are currently 240 women service users on their books. There have been 37 call-outs for their crisis service for recent victims of sexual assault. These are all women in my district.

The women's movement campaigned long and hard for violence against women to be regarded as a crime, regardless of the relationship between the perpetrator and the victim. In this context, it is a damning indictment of the government that, a week before the launch of the groundbreaking `No respect, no relationship' campaign, a group of four men from the Liberal Party, including the Prime Minister's own principal private secretary, pulled the campaign. Women cannot fight this battle on their own. We need real men to speak out against sexual assault and violence. The Prime Minister should immediately release these ads.

It has been almost 30 years since the International Year of Women, and today it is significant to celebrate the achievements of working women. Equal pay for equal work, affirmative action policies and antidiscrimination policies have all made it possible for women to engage in the work force. However, the reality for women in my electorate is that it is becoming increasingly difficult to do so. It is all very well to enact laws and policies encouraging women to enter the paid work force, but this does not make sense if it is not supported by infrastructure that actually allows them to do so. How can women access employment if they are unable to access affordable child care? How can women achieve equal pay if they are not offered paid maternity leave? The reality for many women that I talk to in my role as a federal member is that their lives are severely impacted by lack of access to child care and by work environments that do not support families.

And what of women who are trying to deal with their inability to access and sustain employment by studying while their children are young? What of mature aged women who are working hard to earn a degree so that they can get a well-paid job when their children become independent? One constituent that I have spoken to recently is doing just thatâstudying off-campus so that she will have access to employment when her children have grown up. She has just been informed that her HECS fees are going to increase by 25 per cent and she is seriously questioning whether or not to go on with her degree. These are just some of the barriers facing women in my electorate.

I acknowledge the great gains that have been made; I remember the women who have come before usâthe suffragettes who fought for the vote, who made it possible for me, as a woman, to stand in this place. But when I look around this place I wonder why half the people here are not women. I think of the barriers, both visible and invisible, that serve to keep women out of this House. The continued battle to get a child-care centre in this place has been the worst and most blatant example of `Yes, Minister' policies that I have ever come across.

So today, International Women's Day, I celebrate the courage, tenacity and selflessness of the ordinary women in my electorate who are doing extraordinary work. I acknowledge the women who manage to work despite their lack of access to child care and paid maternity leave, the women who manage to study despite the increasing costs of education and the women who manage the health of their families despite the lack of doctors. I acknowledge my constituents who face barriers not only as women but as women with disabilities. I acknowledge the strength of the survivors of sexual assault and violence, the overwhelming majority of whom are women. For all these women, not only in my electorate but across Australia, we acknowledge today as International Women's Day.

talk.start.para: âWomen's equality has come a long way since International Women's Day was marked for the first time on 19 March 1911. On that date, more than a million men and women attended rallies in several European countries, demanding that women be given the right to vote, the right to work and the right to hold public office. That day was an important day for women around the world, as their struggle for equality and fairness began to take shape as an organised and well-orchestrated campaign. Today, 8 March 2004, is no less important as we look back at what has been achieved and look to a future of continued improvements for women, based on the solid foundations of the past.

speech.para: Throughout history, and long before women's rights and women's suffrage became issues, women were playing their part in the development of Australia. These women were largely unrecognised, but they were true pioneers who carved out a life for themselves and their families in difficult conditions. Individual names stand outâwomen such as Grace Bussell, who in 1876 at the age of 16 plunged into the surf on her horse to snatch a number of women and children from certain death after the ship the SS Georgette broke up in rough seas. The Western Australian town of Busselton is named after her.

In the political arena, Western Australian women are up amongst the firsts. Edith Cowan was elected to the Legislative Assembly of WA in 1921, becoming the first woman parliamentarian in Australia. In 1943 another Western Australian woman, Dorothy Tangney, was elected to the Senate. She and Dame Enid Lyons, who was elected to the House of Representatives in the same year, became Australia's first women Commonwealth parliamentarians. In more recent times, the member for Fremantle, the Hon. Carmen Lawrence, became Australia's first woman Premier when she became Premier of Western Australia in 1990.

In the field of medicine, there are two FionasâStanley and Wood. Professor Fiona Stanley is the founding director of the Telethon Institute for Child Health Research, which was established in Perth in 1990. She was national Australian of the Year for 2003. Dr Fiona Wood made headlines in 2002 when she and her team treated badly burned Bali victims at the Royal Perth Hospital with spray-on skin, her own medical breakthrough that is revolutionising burns treatment. She is head of the Royal Perth Hospital burns unit, the mother of six children and Western Australian of the Year for 2004.

But the majority of working women carry on their daily lives in relative anonymity. While they are not heroes or trailblazers in the public eye, they play a crucial part in the economic lives of their families and the community. In Australia today, 44 per cent of the work force is made up of women. They play an integral and necessary part in Australia's economic fortunes. Women are also the bearers and primary carers of children, and it is in juggling these two things that we have possibly the biggest challenge to equality and fairness for women. Much has been done to assist women and their families in combining these two roles, but there is always room for improvement.

We must continue to encourage family friendly workplaces and flexible working arrangements. However, it is important not to impose legislation that puts such an impost on employers that they would avoid employing women at all. We must increase even further the number of day care places available for our children. Good, affordable child care is an essential element in providing women with the opportunity to enter or remain in the work force and one that the government will continue to address.

We have a situation in Australia today where girls are surging ahead of boys in academic achievements at school and where young women are flocking to universities to pursue further education. We need to encourage these women to take their places in the work force and develop ongoing careers in the fields of science, politics and business. However, staying on a designated career path is often more difficult for women, as their working lives are interrupted to have children and they generally become the custodial parent in the event of a marital breakdown. These factors create a significant barrier to equality in employment for women, and that is something we must continue to address, both for the fulfilment and wellbeing of women and for the future prosperity of the nation. I commend this motion to the House.

talk.start.para: âThe member for Moore has pointed out, on International Women's Day, that we have a world of achievement and success to celebrate as women. But there is also a world of disadvantage, discrimination and violence that we need to acknowledge today of all days. I want to speak briefly about experiences in three countries. I first want to turn to what has been happening in Baghdad. Janet Albrechtsen said in a column not so long ago that feminists were very wrong not to be lauding the successes of the occupying forces in Baghdad and commented on how much easier things are for women in Iraq at the moment. I want to draw the attention of the House to a report by Human Rights Watch, entitled Climate of fear:sexual violence and abduction of women and girls in Baghdad,which was published in July 2003.

speech.para: This report demonstrates that there has been a significant increase in the number of sexual assaults and abductions in Baghdad since the occupying forces took over. The report says there has been a marked failure of the occupying power to protect women and girls from violence and redress it when it occurs. This has both immediate and long-term negative consequences. Girls fear that reporting sexual violence may provoke honour killings and social stigmatisationâor, indeed, forced marriage. Iraq, like a number of other countries, has laws saying that if the perpetrator of the violence will marry the victim afterwards then the crime cannot be prosecuted. So forced marriage, and then continued sexual violence within the marriage, can be a result of reporting.

There are a number of absolutely tragic and compelling case studies within this report, but what is most striking about it is that it seems everyone agrees that there has been a sharp increase in cases of sexual violence since the war. This is partly because of the dramatic reduction in the number of trained police. A lot of them were sacked by the provisional authority because they were too close to the Baath Party. Of course you should not have people who have perpetrated serious crimes in the police force, but that has meant that there is no-one to investigate or prosecute the crimes. There are cases reported in this study of girls as young as nine being abducted and sexually assaulted and then not being able to receive any treatment. The forensic institute in Baghdad is not prepared to treat them, and police are not prepared to pursue or prosecute criminals. In some cases these girls are being taken to American doctors, but it is the tiny minority of people who come to the attention of those authorities.

In an international context, I also wanted to mention an Australian woman who is doing amazing work in Addis Ababa in Ethiopia. Dr Catherine Hamlin, aged 79, is an Australian gynaecologist who has spent the last 44 years in Addis Ababa working on something called obstetric fistulas. As at the last report, she has helped 24,000 women. This condition occurs when a teenage girl cannot deliver a baby properly because the baby is too big for her pelvis. After several days of labour without access to a doctor, the baby dies and the girl is left with a hole between her bladder and vagina or, sometimes, rectum. The result is that urine and sometimes faeces drip constantly down her legs and, in some cases, she is left lame from nerve damage. Women with fistulas are obviously incontinent. They stink and they leave a trail of urine behind them. They are often abandoned by their husbands or other people living in the village.

The author of a report in the New York Times speaks of a girl who was sold into slavery at the age of eight. She was raped by her master at 12 and sent out into the bush at 13 to deliver the baby on her own. After a long labour, she delivered the dead baby by herself but suffered crippling internal injuries, including a fistula. She crawled back to her village, but the baby's father did not want anything to do with her anymore because of the smell. He put her in a hut with the door removed, hoping that the hyenas would kill her during the night. She fought off the hyenas and crawled for a day to reach an American missionary, who took her to the fistula hospital run by Dr Hamlin, where the fistula was repaired. This young woman later became a nurses aide in the hospital. That goes to show what a difference just one person can make. On International Women's Day we should acknowledge not just the work of women like Dr Hamlin but also the millions and millions of women around the world who rely on people like Dr Hamlin to make their lives bearable.

talk.start.para: âToday, women of the world celebrate International Women's Day. The United Nations General Assembly, composed of delegates from every member state, celebrates International Women's Day to recognise that peace and social progress require the active participation and equality of women and to acknowledge the contribution of women to international peace and security. The UN has identified this year's theme as `Women and HIV-AIDS'. Australia is well represented at the international level on women's issues, including this one. This is an occasion to review how far women have come in their struggle for equality, peace and development, to celebrate their achievements and, certainly, to acknowledge how far we still have to go, particularly in the developing nations of the world.

speech.para: Over the past 50 years, the most progress has been achieved in securing political rights for womenâthe right to vote and to be elected. Today there are only a few countries where women cannot vote or run for public office. But only 24 women have been elected as a head of state or government in this century; only 14.1 per cent of representatives elected to parliaments around the world are women; and of the 189 highest ranking diplomats in the United Nations, only 11 are women. Almost no women served on the military staff of UN peacekeeping forces between 1957 and 1979. In 1993, women made up two per cent of the military contingent of peacekeeping forces. Throughout the history of UN peacekeeping, there have only been two women in top decision-making positions. Obviously that is a record that most women in this place would like to improve.

This morning I launched Women's History Month at King O'Malley's pub in Civic on behalf of the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator the Hon. Kay Patterson. This year the theme celebrated the role of Australian women publicans, a role that offered women the opportunity to play such a central part in Australia's social and recreational history. My message for Women's History Month is that, while it is good to look across the Australian and world stages and see the great things women have done, the place to really start this search is within your own familyâfor people to study their mothers, grandmothers, maiden aunts and other ancestors, and to learn and record their stories before those stories slip away.

I want to take a moment to acknowledge rural women. We are small in number and we do require the support of our urban sisters, recognising that we have much more in common than we realise. There are some inspirational women in country areas. They work side by side with their husbands in hard manual work. One such womanâone of my farming constituentsâbattling a medical condition, spent hours a day during the last drought pulling dead and dying sheep out of the mud around the farm waterholes. Women do most of the cooking and cleaning and have primary responsibility for the children. They manage the family finances, itinerary and happiness. They work alone hour after hour, day after day. It is difficult for them to find the time to visit friends and family, who are usually a car trip away. During the recent drought, these women managed the pain of their husbands facing financial crisis and the anxiety of their childrenâand they managed it alone. As their families seemed to be falling apart, they had no choice but to be the ones to hold it all together.

Now that women in general do have choice, they think carefully about their options and the experiences they see around themâthat they observed in their own families, where so many of their mothers entered paid work but were offered no relief on the home front. Modern workplaces still tend to be built around a regime of men working and women doing the household choresâor most of them at least. That is changing. This government has done so much in terms of family tax benefit, child-care assistance, maternity allowances, immunisation support and policies to promote family friendly workplaces.

These are the issues that most concern women of today. They are not fighting the same fight their mothers and grandmothers did, but in many ways this has made life harder, not easier. It is where we are as a society and it is the right place to be, but the challenges are significant. We need women in parliament, in boardrooms, in fields of science, in the military and in the exploration of space. But we need them no less in hospitals, schools, roadside diners, shops and farms. We need women working together with men to come up with answers, but we must move away from the adversarial `men against women' arguments.

While we are talking about adversaries, my profound wish is that we cease using women's issues to play politics in this place. Women will always be represented in all political parties. They will always have strong, passionate contributions to make to the debate, and they will not necessarily be right or wrong. The opposition has made much of the government's campaign against violence in relationships and our supposed indefinite postponement of the campaign. As a current member of the ministerial committee on government communications, I can assure members opposite that this was never the case. Precisely because this issue is so important, we have to get the messages right. If this means revising the materials, so be it. The resources have not been wasted. The campaign will go ahead, and it will be a strong campaign.

Mothers know the feeling when we survey the domestic chaos of our lives and have to walk out to work, and it is not a good feelingâwe feel like unsuccessful parents, homemakers and employees. But we are moving ahead, and we have much support from the policies of the government. And, as my colleague the member for McPherson said, we must spare a thought for women of developing countries who have so little. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
âI move:

speech.para: That this House:
(1) acknowledges the importance and value of international trade and commerce in strengthening bilateral relations between countries;
(2) recognises the enormous economic benefits to Australia of the recently negotiated Free Trade Agreement between Australia and the United States of America; and
(3) calls on the Opposition to support the recently signed Free Trade Agreement between Australia and the United States of America in Australia's long-term national interest.

I am pleased to speak today in the parliament on this motion about the free trade agreement with the United States because it is important and something I am passionate about. As the Minister for Health and Ageing said in question time, this is a once in a generation opportunity for our country. It is in the long-term interests of our country. The free trade agreement is all about jobs. It is all about opportunity and prosperity for our fellow Australians. I do not know what the opposition does not understand about that. Free trade equals jobs, opportunity and prosperity for our country. The historic deal negotiated by the Minister for Trade in February this year will provide tremendous opportunities for Australian exporters. As the federal member for Ryan, I am particularly pleased to represent my constituents and the business people in my electorate who are very export oriented and who are focused on winning export opportunities for their companies, because this agreement translates into jobs and into prosperity for employees and people in the electorate generally.

Australia's export sector is a significant contributor to Australia's economic growth and job creation. Some 1.8 million Australians are employed by exporters of goods and services, and last year trade contributed $147 billion to our economy. The Australia-US free trade agreement is, indeed, a historic trade deal that forms stronger ties between our economy and the world's largest, most dynamic and most innovative economy. According to the OECD, world trade in goods and services in 2002 amounted to $US8,114.4 billion. The World Trade Organisation estimates that the world trade in goods and services in 2002 was $US7,840 billion. The IMF calculates that world exports were $US7,876 billion in 2002 and that they would reach almost $US9,000 billion in 2003. By comparison, according to the OECD, at current prices and exchange rates, Australia's GDP in 2003 was $US508.2 billion. The corresponding estimate from the IMF was some $US493.4 billion. These figures represent the massive difference in the two economies and, correspondingly, the massive opportunities that are presented to Australians in business, trade and commerce.

International trade and commerce play an important role in strengthening bilateral relations between countries. The US is Australia's most important economic partner and our most important security ally. By strengthening our relationship with the US through this free trade agreement, Australia is also increasing its bond with the world's most powerful economy. The Australia-US free trade agreement builds on our relationships with Singapore and Thailand, with whom we negotiated free trade agreements last year. As all members of the parliament would know, we also have framework agreements with Japan and China. We are putting pressure on our trading partners in the region to increase the pace of their reform agendas so that they too are not left behind. This is good for our community, our country and the people that we represent collectively throughout Australia.

With a market of 300-plus million people in the US, this economy offers enormous opportunities for those of us in Australia that are in business or in trade. How could it not be the case that a smaller economy would benefit from dealing in trade and business with the world's largest economy? It defies commonsense that those sitting opposite would seek to put barriers in front of us to prevent us from concluding this agreement. On the weekend, Senator Conroy, one of the roosters in the other chamber, talked about the effects on the PBS not being in our favour. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âIs the motion seconded?
âI second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

âI rise to oppose this motion. I have great respect for the member for Ryan, but I suspect the Prime Minister or the Minister for Trade has prevailed upon the member for Ryan to move such a superficial and cynical motion before he even saw the agreement. Paragraph (1) of the motion `acknowledges the importance and value of international trade and commerce in strengthening bilateral relations between countries'. This is little more than a motherhood statement which could easily have come from a year 9 or year 10 commerce textbook. How can this House, or anyone, automatically recognise, as reflected in paragraph (2) of the motion, `the enormous economic benefits to Australia of the recently negotiated Free Trade Agreement between Australia and the United States of America' when so few of us have had an opportunity to finish reading, let alone analysing, the 1,100 pages that make up the entire agreement? With great respect, I presume the member for Ryan has read the agreement, which was published on the Internet only a few days ago. Notice of this motion was given by the member of Ryan on 17 February 2004, and one cannot be blamed for being cynical about the way such an important issue is being handled by the government. The member gave notice of this motion calling on the House to automatically give unqualified support for an agreement that he had not even seen. Is it any wonder so many people have stopped believing the government when they talk about this agreement?

speech.para: The Australian people have every reason to be cynical, and we have every reason to be cautious. We will be cautious about the agreement and support it only when we are certain that it is in Australia's interest. But it is hard to believe that, in a US election year, President Bush would want to give very much to Australia at the expense of the United States.

One would have to be arrogantly irresponsible to ignore the serious concerns about the FTA being raised in the media every day. It seems to be a strange type of free trade deal that asks Australians to accept the demise of Australia's sugar industry. Equality of opportunity for all Australians is absent in this deal. The large amounts of taxpayers' dollars the government will now have to throw at the sugarcane farmers are testament to that. Many Australians are rightly asking: is this a free trade agreement or just a trade agreement? Let me reiterate. The President of the National Farmers Federation, Peter Corish, wrote in a letter to the editor of the Australian on 17 February 2004:

quote.para: This is not a free trade agreement and it fails to secure open access for Australian agriculture, but it offers improvement in access for some farm products.

speech.para: Ross Gittins wrote in the Sydney Morning Herald on 11 February 2004:

quote.para: The first thing to understand about the free trade agreement with the United States is that, despite the name, it has nothing to do with free trade.

speech.para: Whether you are talking about sugar, agriculture, manufacturing, business visas, foreign investment rules, Australian film and television or the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, there is no denying that genuine concerns remain and they require investigation and assessment before the parliament can responsibly support this FTA.

Many of my constituents in my electorate of Lowe are very worried about the potential damage the FTA will do to the PBS, forcing Australians to pay a great deal more for their medicines. Federal Labor leader, Mark Latham, came to my electorate a little over a month ago to listen to many of my constituents in Five Dock, including a local pharmacist, who shared these concerns. Labor has said that it will not support a trade deal with the US that in any way undermines the PBS, but the government refuses to rule out possible increased costs to Australian taxpayers who subsidise the PBS.

We will also need confirmation that the FTA will not delay the introduction of generic drugs to the market. Any delay in the introduction of generic drugs could also lead to an increase in the cost of the PBS. Now that the full details of the FTA are being examined, there are reports that some of these serious concerns have now been confirmed. On Friday, 5 March 2004, the Australian Financial Review reported:

quote.para: Australia Institute research fellow Richard Denniss said: âThere is no doubt there is going to be adverse impact on the price of medicines under the FTA.â

speech.para: This claim, and many others like it, needs to be examined by the parliament before support for the FTA can be recommended. It is a sensible approach; it is the only approach. This FTA is far too complex and far too important to be forced on the Australian people and the Australian parliament in the highly charged political atmosphere we currently have in Australia and in the United States as both countries face federal elections this year. That is why the opposition announced, on 27 January 2004, that it would refer the trade deal to a Senate select committee to assess whether the deal is in Australia's national interest. The US Congress is allowed three months to scrutinise the trade deal. It is only fair and reasonable that the Australian parliament be given a similar opportunity. The Australian people deserve nothing less.

talk.start.para: âI rise to wholeheartedly support not only the motion moved by the honourable member for Ryan but also the United States-Australia free trade agreement. I do so for three very simple reasons which will have an impact on families in towns throughout my electorateâtowns like Somerville, Hastings, Rosebud and Dromanaâand in rural areas such as Glen Alvie and Lang Lang. Those three reasons are simple. One, it is about jobs; two, it is about income; and three, above all else, it is about living standards. The member for Rankin seems to be amused at these ideas, because what the opposition has done is to stand squarely in the face of an agreement which offers hope and opportunity for Australia.

speech.para: There is an extraordinary historical parallel here. In 1957, Australia completed negotiation of the Japan-Australia trade agreement. That agreement set up much of Australia's prosperity during the latter half of the 20th century, yet that agreement met heavy opposition from the Australian Labor Partyâwith extraordinary parallels between the arguments used then and those that are being used now. Yet Australians throughout Australia would find it ludicrous to look back on that Japan-Australia trade agreement and imagine that it would be opposed, withdrawn or cut up or that anyone would believe that it would, in some way, cause hardship to Australia. Trade is trade. It involves an exchange of goods and services in both directions. We make no apology for that. We believe in that. We believe in Australian consumers being able to get goods at lower prices, and we believe in Australian exporters having access to global markets. In agriculture alone, we export roughly five times what we import, and that is a good thing. There are some imports that we do have to getâthat is the nature of trade, and we make no apologies for that.

There are three conclusions to be drawn from the Australian Labor Party's position in relation to the free trade agreement. First, they say `no new jobs' in the auto sector. They say `no new jobs' in relation to our lamb and sheep producers. They say `no new jobs' in horticulture. That is their position. The second conclusion is that it is ludicrous logic. This is a deal which helps dairy, beef, steel, wine and many other producers, but not sugar. That is true, absolutely. It does not do a thing for sugar producers. The Labor Party say that, because it does not help sugar producers, they will say no to jobs in dairy, beef, steel, wine, manufacturingâany of those sectors. That takes an extraordinary leap of logic and a certain mean-spiritedness which is breathtaking in its scope. The third conclusion is a simple one. The Leader of the Opposition and the member for Rankin will reverse their position. Make no mistake: what they are involved in now is a game. At the end of the day, they will pass this. If they do not then they will stand condemned. I have no doubts about the prediction that the Australian Labor Partyâthe opposition, the alternative governmentâat the end of the day, by the force of logic, by the economic benefit, by the impact for ordinary Australians, will pass this agreement.

The Labor Party can make all the noise that they want to and pretend that they are against this FTA. If that is the case, that is fine; they can oppose it. We will be happy to be judged on the benefits that this brings to Australia. But, at the end of the day, what they are doing now is a fraud. They know it; we know it. What are the benefits? The benefits are simple. In manufacturing, there will be duty-free access, from day one, for over 97 per cent of Australia's manufacturing exports to the United States. In addition to that, there will be duty-free access for more than 66 per cent of our agricultural productsâwith tariffs going to zero from day oneâand an additional nine per cent over a short period of time. So, in a short period of time, three-quarters of our agricultural products will be tariff free.

What is the alternative? The alternative is very simple. The alternative is to do nothing; and if we do nothing, nothing will happen. It is a wonderful policy. The Labor Party are saying that they would forgo the benefits to make the point that something which brings benefits to a multiplicity of sectors may not bring them to every sectorâthat is absolutely true. But at the end of the day this free trade agreement is about jobs and living standards. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI will see if I can lift the tone of the debate here after the contribution of the member for Flinders, who observed, `Trade is trade; it involves an exchange of goods and services.' Well done, member for Flinders! It reminds me of a member of parliament back in the 1970s who observed that traditionally most of Australia's imports come from overseas. Let us see if we can do a little bit better than that.

speech.para: The member for Flinders also asserted that Labor are claiming that there will be no new jobs in the auto industry from this trade deal. In any such assertion, if we had made one, we would rely on the Centre for International Economics, the government's preferred economic modeller, which actually forecast that in the auto industry there would be a contraction in the production of automobiles and components. So the member for Flinders ought to have a look at the government's own report before ascribing that assertion to Labor when in fact it was made by the government's preferred modeller.

The government members pledged their support for this free trade agreement before seeing it. Notice of this motion was given on 17 February, well before the 1,100-page document even arrived. When the Prime Minister and the Minister for Trade said, `Take us on trust', the government members of course did that, as they always do. They accepted the free trade deal as a matter of blind faith. But they should come to understand and appreciate that you cannot trust the Prime Minister or the trade ministerâthe worst trade minister in Australia's history.

The trade minister anticipated this debate in question time today, boasting that Labor never negotiated a preferential bilateral trade deal. For once in his life, the minister was right: we did not negotiate a preferential bilateral trade deal. We have never negotiated a preferential bilateral trade deal, and the reason is that we support non-discriminatory, non-preferential trade deals. Labor in government negotiated the opening up of markets in Japan, China and Korea for commodities such as beef and wool, but we did it on a non-discriminatory basis. We said to those countries, `We'll take our chances in the global competitive race,' and that is what happened. Those countries did open up their markets to those commodities, to the great benefit of rural Australia. Labor support multilateral trade negotiationsânot a word from the member for Flinders on multilateral trade negotiations.

Through the free trade agreement, the government has signalled to our multilateral trade negotiators and, more importantly, to other multilateral trade negotiators with whom we are currently negotiating that it considers that no extra access for sugar is acceptable in the multilateral trade negotiations in the WTO Doha round. It has signalled that because that is the deal that the Australian government has struck with the US administration in the trade agreement. The Australian government is signalling loud and clear that it is acceptable for there to be no progress on sugar; it is signalling that it is acceptable for there to be long delays in access for beef; and it is signalling that it is acceptable for price triggers to be put in place to protect American agriculture from Australian exportsâprice triggers that apply to well over 20 commodities. When government members supported this motion, they were unaware of it, but it has not affected their thinking at all because they are acting with blind faith in this government.

Government MPs have signed up to a trade deal with the United States that puts at risk the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and severely restricts access for Australia's textile and clothing industries through very restrictive rules of originâagain, to which the members opposite are completely oblivious and completely indifferent. Members opposite, if they have any interest in the textile and clothing industries in this country, should be concerned that the rules of origin mean that we will not enjoy the access to the US market that was claimed by this government before we saw the 1,100 pages of the free trade agreement. It allows the US to lift protection for other agricultural products. And so it goes on.

We simply do not know if this deal is in Australia's national interest. The smartest thing to do would be to ask the Productivity Commission to do an objective analysis. Instead the government is putting it out to tender, and we know what the problems will be there: it will set the assumptions for the tenderers, and no doubt the government's preferred economic modeller will be selected to get the predetermined results it wants, which will convince no-one. Certainly, we want to know whether this trade deal is in Australia's national interest. That should be the test. The Productivity Commission should do that workâobjectively, fairly and honestly. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to congratulate the member for Ryan on moving this motion. I would also very much like to congratulate our Minister for Trade, Mark Vaile, on having done something that no-one elseâcertainly, not from an Australian point of viewâhas been able to do in the past: crack the biggest world market that exists. We are talking about a market that is one-third of the world's gross domestic product. It is the biggest market anywhere. Even China's economy, for all the talk about it, is only one-eighth the size of the American economy.

speech.para: What does the free trade agreement with the United States do? The members opposite seem to have trouble getting through some very simple basics. There are huge gains for manufacturing, as you have just heard from my colleague the member for Flinders, not the least of which are in the automobile industry. The agreement also enables Australian firms to be involved in US government procurement, a market worth $200 billion. Never before have Australian companies had the opportunity to bid for US government goods and services.

For an electorate like mine, totally revolving around exports, this is something that had to happen. Whether those exports are horticulture, lamb, beef, dairy or forest products, this agreement has allowed us into a market that we basically had no entree into. All this talk about what a bad deal this is obviously comes from people with absolutely no knowledge of trade and absolutely no knowledge of the fact that Australia did not have too much to lose on any deal that it might have done. I have to point out something to those who cannot get this through their heads: we just heard the member for Rankin taking the high moral ground on multilateral trade deals, saying that we have to talk free trade around the world or not at all, but that is not much good to somebody who is an exporter and who is waiting to increase their access to other markets, and specifically the best market in the world, right now.

Before he starts criticising the person who is obviously the best trade minister we have had, the member for Rankin needs to pay attention to the multiplying effect on Australian trade around the world that has occurred over the last six years. What he needs to pay attention to is what our Minister for Trade, Mark Vaile, has done in recent years. The minister has got off the high moral ground and got very practical. This is not just about using bilateral one-on-one trade deals. As you have heard, we have done them with Singapore, Taiwan and other countries, but the fact is that we now use every lever available to us. We have taken the US to the WTO disputes committee, and we have won. We have done the same with Korea. You have to do those things. You have to get off the high moral ground, get practical and help exporters in places like the electorate of Parkes. To us, it is absolutely essential.

I have to comment on the fact that recently people like the member for Rankin and a lot of the members opposite have said, `You have not read the fine print. Do you realise that the US can put a hold on things if there is an enormous price drop in some of the agricultural commodities mentioned?' What country would not want to make sure that nobody can dump product in their country and that there is a safeguard there if an enormous price fall occurs? We would do it. Any country would do that. The difference is the Americans have such high protection against every countryâincluding Australiaâthat they have a long way to go. We have very little protection. You cannot get it through the heads of those opposite that really we had very little to lose in this deal and an awful lot to gainâand we have.

Regarding the beef industry, the opposition are talking about the agreement as though the beef industry has not gained. We have only once since quotas existed filled a quota, and that was only because Japan shut its doors because of the threat of mad cow disease. This deal will allow Australia's beef industry to expand at a considerable rate and still not meet that beef quota in the next 15 to 18 years. It does not matter. When you look at sheep meat and wool, you see that within four years there will be no problems for them at all. Horticulture and the wine industry have an awful lot to gain in a very short time. The opposition need to open their eyes, wake up and learn what trade means. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am one of the millions of Australians who have not yet managed to read the 1,100 pages of the document known as the proposed free trade agreement. Most Australians never will get the opportunity to read it, so I guess it is incumbent on us as parliamentary representatives to speak up on their behalf. In my case, I want to raise some concerns on behalf of my constituents, as we and they try to understand the impact that a deal negotiated on the other side of the Atlantic will have on the daily lives of ordinary Australiansâin particular those living in my constituency.

speech.para: The government promotes the free trade agreement as the best thing to happen to Australia since sliced bread. From the Prime Minister down, government ministers urge that we all support this deal unequivocally, the suggestion being that if the Labor opposition do not pass this free trade agreement we will in some way be unpatriotic or, as Minister Downer quite foolishly asserted last week, anti-American.

The role of the opposition in this parliament is to apply maximum scrutiny. Precisely because the free trade agreement is a significant event, in our national interest we cannot take the proposals on good faith alone. To do so would be to abrogate our responsibility and let the Australian people down. The government may not be happy with this, but we live in a democracy and that is how things work in a democracy. I can understand that the government is eager for Labor to pass its free trade agreement but, while I agree that we are presented with an important opportunity, I am also mindful that this agreement was forged in an election year for both the Howard government and the Bush administration. As a result, we have every reason to be concerned about the politics surrounding the fine print.

The Prime Minister wants his 15 minutes of fame, and good luck to him. But he will have to wait for the outcome of the Senate inquiry, because only through an inquiry can we get the answers to the many questions that are now emerging around the free trade agreement and what it means for Australia's agriculture, for its manufacturing sector, for pharmaceutical benefits, for the car industry, for the film industry and so onâthe list goes on. The ABS 2001 census notes that my electorate of Calwell has 15,000 people working in textile, footwear and clothing factories, as well as in car, plastics and chemical manufacturing. These industries will rely heavily on a free trade agreement that is free and fair, one that allows them to continue to operate competitively so that they can continue to be successful and provide jobs for the thousands of workers and their families who live in Calwell. Workers, trade unions and economic analysts are concerned, for example, that the $2 billion per year increase in imports of US manufactured goods could lead to Australian job losses. Although in my electorate the Ford motor company has cautiously welcomed the agreement, there is concern about Australian markets being swamped by US cars. I am sure my Ford factory workers want to know what that may mean for their jobs and their futures.

What does the free trade agreement mean for Lanes Biscuits in Coolaroo, whose competitive exports may be penalised as a result of the proposed increase in sugar surcharges? What does the free trade agreement mean for Yakka, a 70-year-old icon based in Broadmeadows, already under pressure from reduced tariffs? It and other clothing and footwear companies may have to compete with a flood of American imports on an unequal footing, given that the detail of the agreement shows that the US has won special rules on textiles, making it harder for local TCF exporters to enter the US market.

What do we make of the Prime Minister stating that tariffs will be phased out, while the US trade representative says they will go `immediately'? Whom are we to believe or trust on this vital issue? I can tell you that my constituents expect their government to protect their interests and to protect their jobs. They expect a government to act in the national interest, ensuring that Australian industries are protected against unfairness and unlevel playing fields.

We do recognise the enormous economic potential for Australia that could come from linking into the world's biggest economy, and we appreciate our relationship with the US. But we should be mindful that it is not a special relationship. The Prime Minister might see it as such, but we cannot define our national interest in the narrow context of the Prime Minister's friendship with President Bush. Each responsible national leader realises that their nation's interests must be first and foremost. To the United States, the Australian free trade agreement is but one of many FTAs it will negotiate. The US negotiates overwhelmingly and primarily in its interest, and so it should. Australia must do the same. Certainly the Labor opposition will insist on nothing less than this. To grab a deal simply for the sake of having one is a `something is better then nothing' approach which may have negative consequences down the track after all the dust has settled.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

âIn May this year the government will release the details of the much talked about national road transport plan, or AusLink as it is called by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services, John Anderson. I think the government may be a little bit confused about what it wants to do with roads and road funding and, in fact, about what AusLink is about. I think most people would understand that there are three levels of funding for roads: the national system, which the federal government fundsâand has done for many years; the state system; and the local system. While the government may be confused about this, people in the street are not. They understand the three different levels at which they are funded.

speech.para: AusLink will detail the government's long-term plans in relation to funding for road and rail infrastructure. However, I do not think we need to wait until May to find out exactly what AusLink has in store for most Australians. It is already clear from statements made by the government that many communities, like those in the electorate of Oxley, will be let down. I want to explain why that is the case. It is widely known that under the Constitution the Commonwealth government has no specific responsibility for roads. I acknowledge that. Nevertheless, road funding has been an important part of the federal government's responsibilities for many years. The Commonwealth accounts for about one-fifth of all government road-related expenditure and so exerts some influence over the level and disposition of funding. The centrepiece of Commonwealth road funding is the national highway. I want to make a big point of that. The centrepiece of the responsibility of the federal government is the national highway systemâand in my electorate of Oxley that is as true as it is anywhere else. One of the most important roads in Queensland is the Ipswich Motorway. It is an important part of the national highway system, as well as being a major road that services south-east Queenslandâand specifically south-west Brisbane and Ipswich. I will return to the issue of that specific motorway in a moment.

It was the Whitlam government that first assumed full financial responsibility for the national highway, back in 1974. Since that time the national highway has expanded, but the Commonwealth still retains full responsibility for that system. This, however, appears certain to change under this government and under AusLink. The federal Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads, Senator Ian Campbell, has confirmed recently that the government is not prepared to accept full responsibility for the funding of the national road system. Of course, you have to ask yourself, `If the government's not prepared to fund it, then who will be responsible for our national federal highway system?' Funding for this system, the senator says, should be a shared responsibility. This is unacceptable. Shared responsibility is terminology for, `We are going to cherry pick. We will pick what we will share and we will pick what we will not share.' That is unacceptable. I want to reaffirm here my 100 per cent support for responsibility for the construction and maintenance of the national highway network staying with the Commonwealth. That should be the responsibility of the federal government.

The people of Oxley know all too well what AusLink will mean for the Ipswich Motorway. It is that first little wedgeâand it is not even little; it is a big wedgeâwhich will mean that we will not get the funding we need in our area for our roads. A detailed look at national funding for highways since the Howard government came into power reveals a very interesting trend. That trend is that since election nothing has changed. Funding has not changed. It has remained static. In fact, it has gone down a tiny little bitâby an amount that is not really worth noting. But, in real dollar terms over those eight years, that means there has been a substantial decrease in the amount of money that actually goes into our national highway system. So when people today look at the national highway system and say that it has gone to rack and ruin, it is no wonder that it has, because the reality is that the federal government has not met its full responsibilities. So, while we now know what its policy is in writingâthat it no longer feels it should be responsibleâit has already been implementing that policy for many years.

No real increase in funding to the national highway system since the Howard government claimed power has meant that the maintenance and construction costs for the roads in that system have blown out today, making it a much more expensive operation to run. The government intends to shift some of its responsibilities to fund the national highway. In the 2002-03 financial year, 45 per cent of Commonwealth road funding was devoted to the national highway system, with all those funds going towards maintenance and construction. Are we expected to believe that the government is going to commit more money? Under AusLink they are saying that it is about more money and about committing more dollars but, judging by everything I have read about AusLink and the national road transport plan, it is actually about shifting responsibility. It is not about delivering better outcomes; it is about making other people take up the slack from this government.

So, if no more money is expected to flow into the national highway system, where does that leave the residents of Oxley and south-east Queensland? What about the Ipswich Motorway? I will tell you where it leaves them: exactly where they have been left by this government for the last six yearsânowhere. For the last six years the government has obfuscated. It has done absolutely everything it could to avoid its responsibilities. It has not made one commitment or provided one bit of real funding to upgrade the Ipswich Motorway. There have been bits and pieces here and thereâin particular the $66 million, about which I have always said, `If this government provides the funding we need for the road, I will congratulate it.' It is okay to say, `Thanks very much for the $66 million for emergency repairs and emergency maintenance.' That is fine, but what about the real work of maintaining this road and doing a proper job? The people of south-east Queensland, including the people of Oxley and the people of the Liberal seat of Blair, drive on that road almost every dayâif not every day. They know the dramas and hassles of that and they know how dangerous that road is, and they want to see it fixed.

That leads me to several other issues I want to raise. One in particular is safety. I want to make it clear on the public record that upgrading this road is not an and/or thingâthis is not a choice between this road and some other road; this is a safety issue. The road needs to be upgraded for safety reasons. It is not just about capacity and it is not just about traffic flows; it is about how safe that road is for the mums and dads that travel along it every day. Right now it is one of Australia's worst and most dangerous roads. It is killing our economy and it is hurting peopleâit is causing accidents every day. That is the first issue I want to note.

The second issue is the issue of responsibility for the road. It has always been the responsibility of the federal government to fund that road. That is a federal national highway system road. While we can share responsibilities in terms of how we put it together, it has always been very clear that the states have the peopleâthe engineers in the department, who actually determine how to fix itâand the Commonwealth funds it. There has never been a debate about that, but the Commonwealth government now says that it does not like the umpire. It does not like the decisions of the state Labor government, so it is not going to fund it. It says, `Find us some other solution. Keep finding solutions until we find an answer.' Of course, when somebody does not want to hear an answer, you are never going to find anything that satisfies them. I now know why for so many years the government has refused to be happy with any outcomes of the state government: because it was never going to pay for that road in the first place.

The idea of other roadsâand I am talking about alternative roadsâis one that is very much confused in this whole debate, but it is something I want to talk about. This road, the Ipswich Motorway, needs to be fixed as a stand-alone project, regardless of how many alternatives and other roads we construct or pay for. I think that is the beauty of thisâthe fact that it is really simple: let's fix the Ipswich Motorway. Let us upgrade it to six lanes and do a proper job. Then let us talk about other roads. Or we can do it at the same timeâit does not worry me: we can chew gum and walk and breathe all at the same time. That is okay. But this government obviously seems to have problems with that. It can only deal with one issue at a time.

And of course there is the issue of politics. The government and government members, particularly the member for Blair, have made a really big deal about the issue of timing: `We cannot fix this road, because it will disrupt traffic.' If you really sit down and think about what he means when he says that, what is he saying? Is he saying that we cannot fix any road because it will disrupt traffic? That, of course, is just silly. The reality is that there will be traffic disruptions and there will be delays, but if we do not do something nowâif we just walk away and say, `Well, it's too hard,'âwe reach a point when the road will cease to operate; it will cease to be an effective road. So this argument of the government's about how long it will take and all the rest of it is really a silly oneâand again it is just about playing for time.

Who decides what the road will look like is caught up in the same old tired politics. It does not matter what you do in putting together community consultation and spending millions of dollars on consultations with engineers and on reports that are 1,000 pages tall. The reports are three feet tall but, after having spent two years doing all that work consulting people and looking at the best possible options, a government member turns around and says, `Well, that's not good enough, because I reckon'âa personal opinionâ`that is not the option we should go for; we should go for some other option that is completely untested.' Two years of work and community consultation and $4 million of expenditure are swept aside by one government member, the member for Blair, saying that in his view we should just go somewhere else. That is just a ludicrous proposition, but these are the sorts of arguments that are being put forward here.

I did not want to make this into a political issue, but unfortunately it has turned into one because the government refuses to accept its responsibilities. We are talking about a road in the national highway system, and the federal government should pay for it. I am deeply disturbed about the AusLink proposals, because what they do is almost guarantee that there will be no government funding for vital roads in Queenslandâparticularly the Ipswich Motorway.

talk.start.para: âIn this grievance debate, it is fitting that I follow the member for Oxley and his discussion on roads, because this afternoon I grieve for the situation regarding the failure to construct the Scoresby and Eastern Freeway in Melbourne's outer east and for the way in which the community there has been let down, abandoned and deceived by the Bracks government in Victoria, with the full support and agreement of those oppositeâor, at best, their acquiescence. For those in the Australian community who feel that more needs to be done to improve the level of trust in institutions and to strengthen the fabric of our democracy and that more needs to be done if leaders and politicians are to regain what has been lost in public confidence, there is no greater example of why this is the case than the sorry tale of the Scoresby Freeway and Labor's cynical and dishonest actions in that regard. There is no greater example in recent political memory of a breach of public trust than the breathtaking way in which the people of Melbourne's outer east and Yarra Valley were pledged and promised a toll-free freeway before the last state election, only to see that pledge and that promise dumped and ignored after the election. The Bracks Labor government's actions have not only plumbed a new low-water mark for broken promises; more importantly, they provide a graphic early warning not just to the people of Melbourne's eastern suburbs but to all Australians about the true value of Labor's word on any subject, the lengths to which Labor, state or federal, will go to win votes and the equal speed with which they will then callously act to betray any trust given to them.

speech.para: In the leadup to the state election in Victoria in November 2002, Steve Bracks not only reaffirmed his solemn pledge to build a toll-free freeway and deliberately made it a central feature of his campaign but also went a step further: he made a personal pledge to each and every family in the outer-east region community. He made that personal commitment precisely because he acknowledged there was voter doubt over Labor's record on road funding. He made that personal promise and pledge to override and eliminate any doubt that might exist in the public mind. He did it in order to ensure that every voter in the outer east and in the Yarra Valley knew that Labor would honour its word. He sent a letter to every household in that community in the dying days of the election campaign. In that letter he made this statement:

quote.para: Labor will build the Scoresby Freeway on time and on budget. These are not just election time promises, they are my firm commitments to you and your family and they will be honoured.

speech.para: That was a personal commitment, above party politics; it was a personal undertaking; it was a contract between Steve Bracks and each and every resident. It was an attempt by Steve Bracks to say, `Of all the promises the Labor Party has ever made, I promise you that this one will be delivered on time and in full.' He could not have been any more definite. He could not have elevated the importance of the promise and the importance of that toll-free freeway any further. He could not have constructed a bigger stack of Bibles upon which to swear his word. It was a pledge of such unmistakable clarity givenâand repeated over and over againâwith such force that, happily for Bob Hawke and Paul Keating, it even eclipses their most infamous promises about no child living in poverty and l-a-w tax cuts.

That is why this issue is so relevant to the Australian community in the leadup to the next election. Often before a federal election the public wonder what an opposition might be like in government. This time noone need wonder; they need only look at the actions of Bracks Labor to know what the actions of Latham Labor would be. They have an early release and an early take on what federal Labor's approach would be.

Every Labor promise, every Labor pledge and every Labor commitment must now be viewed through the prism of the Scoresby Freeway. Every Labor pledge is a Scoresby pledge. The fact that Labor will break faith on their most solemn and concrete of promises in the area of roads means they will do it on any policy in any and every area of government. If the Victorian Labor leader will deceive the people of Melbourne so blatantly, so too will the federal Labor leader across the country. If the Victorian Labor leader will happily break a cast-iron pledge and betray the trust of the community by tearing up the unequivocal pledges he signs his very name to, so too will the Leader of the Opposition in the federal parliament. It means there is not a promise that Labor are prepared to make that they are not prepared to break. More than that, it shows that federal Labor will make big promises, with their hands on their hearts, in the leadup to the next election in the full knowledge that they will never be delivered. It means federal Labor's promises on health, on education, on anything, must be treated as Scoresby promisesâretractable pledges offered before an election, ready to be snatched back afterwards should Labor ever be elected.

The public are entitled to this view not just because of the actions of the Bracks government, which are a preview of what would come and an early warning system for what would identically occur across Australia, but also because this federal Labor leader and the previous failed incumbent, the member for Hotham, had backed Bracks and his dishonest backdown on Scoresby with deafening, accepting and compliant silence. Feeble excuses about the issue now being none of their businessâdesperate attempts to dismiss the issue as purely a state concernâdefy reality and the facts. The federal government is a partner to a signed contract to jointly fund the construction of a toll-free freeway. But, more than that, prior to the last federal election federal Labor made precisely the same pledgeâthat if elected they would fund half of the construction of the Scoresby Freeway on the condition there would be no tolls.

In October 2001, just on the eve of the federal election, the then and now shadow Treasurer, the member for Hotham, and the then and now shadow minister for transport, the member for Batman, released Labor's roads policy under the heading `Labor delivers the total Scoresby solution' and made a feature of the fact that their policy was an example of how federal and state Labor could work together for ordinary Australians. Given federal Labor also pledged its support for a toll-free freeway and sought to make a virtue of its superior and influential relationship with the Bracks government, you would have thought that it would have at least expressed a level of opposition or disappointment when the Bracks government betrayed the people of Melbourne. But, no, there was not a word when Bracks made his announcement on April 14 last year; there was not a word all of last yearâjust silence. Federal Labor's so-called total Scoresby solution has been total Scoresby silence, total acquiescence and total weakness. In the 11 months since that Bracks backdown, the member for Hotham and former Leader of the Opposition has, to the best of anyone's research, not uttered a single word on this subject, let alone a condemnation of his state colleagues. There is no evidence anywhere that he has ever actually uttered the word `Scoresby'. Ditto for the member for Batman, who has only recently broken his silence after 10 months of mute collaboration with state Labor. But even now he will not pledge to be part of building a toll-free road.

The residents of the outer east and the Yarra Valley have learned the value of federal Labor's word and the priority Labor place on their needs. It is quite simple. In a choice between standing up for the residents of Melbourne or covering up for the Bracks government, they have happily chosen the latter. In a choice between vigorously opposing deceit on the part of the Bracks government or weakly condoning it, again they have chosen the latter. The new Leader of the Opposition has had a lot to say on a lot of subjects, including public trust in institutions and democracy in parliament, and no doubt he will have more to say in the leadup to the federal election, but the people of Melbourne will know and be reminded, as will the people across Australia, that his words, his pledges and probably even his signed lettersâlike those of Mr Bracks on every subject, be it roads, health or educationâcan go straight in the Bracks file marked `promises ready to be broken'.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to express my dismay and disappointment with the Victorian state member for Warrandyte, Mr Phil Honeywood. Mr Honeywood crept into the Victorian parliament at 2 a.m. last Thursday night to express his outrage at a decision of the Victorian planning minister to invoke section 20(4) of the Planning and Environment Act 1987. He claims the minister's decision is a shock and has been adopted without consultation with council or the local community. The only shock is that this local member is so out of touch with his community that he does not realise the significance of this decisionâa decision which has the backing of the local council and which is being heralded by the entire Chinese community in Victoria as a lifesaver. The member for Warrandyte, who used to have ministerial responsibility for multiculturalism, should be more attuned to the needs of the ethnic community and, more importantly, to the large numbers of Chinese who live in his seat.

speech.para: The decision will allow the development of the first Chinese specific nursing home in Victoriaâthe `on luck' nursing home, a much-needed facility for this growing and ageing community. In my electorate of Chisholm alone there is a large and growing Chinese community, which is well serviced by the Chinese Community Social Services Centre Inc. The centre has been in existence for 11 years and has provided an excellent range of services to the Chinese community in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne. The centre currently provides a comprehensive community aged care service, which includes an extensive home and community care package and 50 community aged care packages. This work and research conducted by the CCSSCI has demonstrated an underutilisation of mainstream nursing homes by the Chinese community and an emerging need for an ethno-specific home to cater to the growing Chinese community in Victoria. Put simply, the Chinese within the community find mainstream nursing homes too foreign for them. There are massive language, cultural and dietary problems with going into these nursing homes, so fundamentally they do not take up places in them.

According to the 1996 census, there were 5,657 Chinese-speaking people over the age of 65 in metropolitan Melbourne. The Chinese Community Social Services Centre has estimated this number will increase significantly, with the influx of aged migrants from mainland China, to around 8,000. In accordance with the Commonwealth government standard of 40 nursing home beds per 1,000 people aged 70 plus, there is a need for 322 beds to be designated to Chinese-speaking elderly citizens.

On the federal government's operational benchmark for aged care, the figures of the Department of Human Services reveal that Victoria is more than 5,000 beds short. The department's bed census for March 2001 demonstrates that, in the catchment area for Chisholm, patients who have been assessed for nursing home care are waiting for an average of 28 days in hospital for a nursing home bed, with 20 per cent waiting in excess of 71 days. The Chinese Community Social Services Centre currently offers extensive services to the Chinese community, and much of its work is now focused on the needs of the elderly in the community, as this is a growing area of demand. The centre is finding that many frail elderly people are remaining in their homes past the point where they can be adequately cared for, as they find mainstream services too alienating for their needs.

The centre has now been awarded 60 high-care aged care bed licences and $1.1 million in capital funding to assist with building the first ethno-specific Chinese home in Victoria. The nursing home will cater for all Chinese speakers regardless of country of origin and will be a not-for-profit establishment. The facility will cater for all of the Chinese community and will ensure there are provisions for concessional beds and assisted residents. The Chinese Community Social Services Centre and the Chinese community have now launched a major fundraising effort to help find the additional money needed to make this long-held dream a reality. Two people in particular on the centre's board need special thanks and praise for their tireless efforts in making this vision a reality: Fred Cheu and Kim Chua. Their work in securing federal funding and bed licences, their fundraising drive and their tenacity to have the state minister accommodate the building of their home on a piece of land they had purchased prior to legislation changing should be praised by the member for Warrandyte in Victoria, not condemned.

I want to put on record my thanks to the Victorian Minister for Planning for her sensible decision in this area and let her know this is a very welcome decision to the Chinese community, particularly those in my seat of Chisholm and within the Chinese Community Social Services Centre, which operates in Box Hill in my area. The member for Warrandyte in Victoria should stand condemned for not knowing what is going on in his own backyard and for not assisting these people, who are in a crisis situation. He should be thanking the government for overturning what could have been a perilous situation for them had they not been able to build on a piece of land they had bought. Instead we will now see a much-needed ethno-specific nursing home going ahead.

On the issue of aged care, while I do welcome and have welcomed the government's support for the `on luck' nursing home, I want to know what it has to say to the 600 residents at Inala village in East Burwood. Whilst this nursing home is outside my electorate, there are many families in my electorate who have loved ones living at Inala. The member for Deakin has a lot to say about roads, but what does he have to say about aged care? What has he sought from the minister to assist the 600 residents of this Salvation Army home slated for sale? Many of the residents are retired Salvation Army officers who have lived on a pittance during their lives of service to others and have had, until now, a home in retirement as part of their conditions. With the sale of Inala this will be lost.

The staff of Inala and Salvation Army officers locally have come under some flack for this decision. This is unfair and unwarranted. The culprit here is the federal government, which has failed to address the crisis in aged care, which has failed to answer the Salvos' pleas for financial assistance, which has failed to appropriately fund aged care and which has done nothing to assist the frail and elderly of Inala. A buyer for Inala will be hard to find, as it is a large and old facility which needs significant upgrades. These upgrades will be needed just to bring it into compliance. It is a place with not only a low- and high-care facility but also many independent living units. What is the government doing to assist these residents and their families who are living with constant uncertainty about their futures? It is all right to come in here and talk about roads, but what is the federal government doing about a most important issue in our areaâaged care? I am constantly contacted by families and friends of residents in Inala who are coping with loved ones who are already old and, in some cases, a bit confused. This has just created a greater uncertainty in their lives and needs to be dealt with urgently.

The issue of ageing has been put in the spotlight with the Treasurer's recent pronouncement that demography is destiny. Apparently he received quite a deal of praise in his party room for his speech in this area. What I would like to know is: where is the real reform in this area? Where is some genuine hope for people going into retirement? What is the Treasurer doing now to ensure that people who are younger than me are actually earning enough for their retirement? There was nothing in his speech to say that he was going to be encouraging people to save sensibly for retirement. What was his great advice? Work till you drop. Some people might want to do that, but people who have been in physically demanding work all their lives probably cannot do that and, furthermore, might want to sit down and rest for a while.

It is all well and good for the Treasurer to keep talking about the 55-year-old executive who might want to work on parttime after having decided that they do not want to retire completely. There are not that many 55-year-old executives out there. Actually, the majority of executives I know do not make it to 55 while still in the work force. The majority I have dealt with were made redundant well and truly by the time they were 50 and have been very frustrated in looking for work since that time. They know all too well that age discrimination is rife in the work force.

When I was at the Finance Sector Union prior to coming to this place, I was dealing constantly with men, particularly men aged 40-plus, who had been made redundant and were looking around for work. Sadly, a lot of them decided that their next big enterprise would be to open a franchise.
