I do not know if anybody noticed, as I did, that there was a plethora of cheesecake shops opening up all over the place. Redundant bank workers thought that a franchise was going to be their way to go. Sadly, a lot of these failed because they were not given assistance or guidance in how to run a small business; they had been working in big banks in big institutions. They did not know how to adapt to small business. The Treasurer's speech did nothing to assist them or others to find work.

A wonderful organisation called 45-Plus has just been advised that it will no longer receive federal funding. This group has been assisting workers aged 45-plus back into the work force. Workers aged 45-plus are invisible. They do not receive Centrelink payments, predominantly because they are still living on their redundancy payouts or their partners are in part-time work. 45-Plus is a wonderful organisation which has received state government fundingâit is grateful to the state government for the fundingâbut its federal funding has been cut and it will not be able to service its programs. Where is the support for the aged in our community?

talk.start.para: âI am extraordinarily concerned that Australia's outstanding productivity performance could be destroyed if ever the Australian Labor Party came to power under its current policy proposals. All small businesses in this country should listen very carefully to the following information, which is a compilation of Labor Party policy, a compilation of the facts of what Labor would do if it were elected to government. All small businesses listening to any one of these policies will understand the havoc it would wreak on their business and, consequently, the havoc it would wreak on Australia.

speech.para: Labor has continually opposed the coalition's industrial relations program, which has provided more flexibility and choice in individual workplaces. Under this program we have the most outstanding economy in the developed world, inflation has been kept under control and productivity and real wages have increased. When I have spoken to people in the electorate, I have found that they are very happy. If we return to a union controlled award system, which existed in the 1970s, God help Australia. This is what the ALP national platform proposes.

Labor proposes to abolish Australian workplace agreements, which are very popular, and the Employment Advocate and plans to restore the role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. We all know how ineffective that commission was. Mark Latham, in an address to the ALP conference in January this year, indicated that that would be Labor's policy. Small businesses listening to this broadcast this afternoon will be alarmed to know that Labor will allow unlimited strike action without secret ballots, drastically reducing workplace productivity. That is also in the ALP national platform.

Labor would provide a right of entry for trade union officials into workplaces, regardless of whether they employ union membersâ imagine trade union officials knocking on the door of any small business, even if it is in the back street area of a city or town, whether or not union members are employedâfor the purposes of communication, organisation, recruitment and assistance to workers. And we all know what that means.

Labor would legislate the rights of union delegates in the workplace, including the right to reasonable time off to consult with other workers and participate in the affairs of the union, and the right to trade union education and access to appropriate facilities, including to disseminate relevant trade union information, including by email.

Labor wants to formalise arrangements for casual workâI encourage small businesses to listen very carefully to this particular policyâby attaching holiday and sick pay benefits and giving casual workers the right to demand hours of work that suit them. What would this country come to if casual workers, who are already paid a loading, double dip, according to the Labor Party, and get holiday and sick pay? This policy would force businesses to pay casual workers their existing higher wages plus the benefits that come with full-time jobs. That was announced by Craig Emerson in the Australian Financial Review on 28 January this year.

Labor wants to give workers on maternity leave the right to come back to work part time for up to five years after the birth of a child. If you are a manager responsible for running the business efficiently and profitably, how would you cope with that? What cost would that impose on a small business?

Labor would remove the protection that businesses have from secondary boycotts under the Trade Practices Actâlandmark legislation enacted by this government which has markedly improved the figures on time lost due to strikesâand has voted against legislation that would enable the ACCC to seek compensation on behalf of innocent third-party small businesses affected by union action. This kind of action can drive innocent third parties out of business. Labor wants to return to the bad old days where a business, which has nothing to do with the original dispute, can be driven out of business and not be able to seek compensation. That is wrong and unfair.

Labor has refused to support legislation to remove unfair dismissal laws for small business and has voted against it 39 times. Labor will bring the Australian waterfront back under the control of the unions, which does not surprise me. We all know what that might mean. The Australian waterfront is now world competitive. The unions said that it never would be, but it now is. Labor wants to go back to the bad old daysâwe all know what they wereâwhich would have an enormous negative effect on the Australian economy and on exporters' incomes.

Labor refuses to rule out requiring businesses to pay for some or all of its promised 14 weeks paid maternity leave. Labor refuses to support reforms from the Cole royal commission to stop lawlessness, rorts and intimidation in the building and construction industry. Labor would use its procurement policies in governmentâand I could not believe this when I first heard it come out of the ALP national conferenceâto favour companies taking a positive approach to the rights of trade unions. Goodness me! Do we all understand what that means?

Comments from Mark Latham indicate that Labor would support legislation to regulate independent contractors and, in most cases, deem them to be employees even though they are independent contractors. Labor has gleefully announcedâand this is what is behind all of thisâthat it is now back in partnership with the trade union movement. There is nothing wrong with being back in partnership with the trade union movement, but when the trade union movement as a body outside this parliament runs the Australian Labor Party for the benefit of the trade union movement itself and not of the country that development becomes of extraordinary concern. I think there are some serious questions that need to be faced up to and some serious decisions from small businesses required as to how they feel about all of this.

On top of that, just to make the lives of small business people a little harderâbecause the Labor Party would not want small business to be doing well as that might benefit employees!âLabor is going to put up taxes. We have seen evidence of that in parliament this afternoon during question time. Labor has refused to rule out an increase in company tax, and Mark Latham has repeatedly refused to rule out business tax hikesâ

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)âThe member for Herbert will refer to members by their seat or title.

âI should, Mr Deputy Speaker; you are absolutely correct. The Leader of the Opposition has repeatedly refused to rule out business tax hikes to fund any Labor reductions in PAYE taxes. Labor will introduce a new 0.1 per cent levy on payrolls to fund a national insurance scheme for worker entitlements, and it will reverse the coalition's decision to increase the diesel fuel rebate to mining companies, slugging the industry with an effective $467 million tax hike. Labor has opposed the coalition's reform to Australia's international tax arrangements and the franked dividend rebate, which together deliver tax savings of some $490 million over four years. (Time expired)

âIn an answer to a question on notice last November, the Minister for Health and Ageing supplied me with the following information. In the state of Victoria in the year 2002-03, there were 39,758,000 PBS prescriptions filled. In the electorate of Scullin in the same financial year, there were 1,002,929. That is roughly an average of 10 scrips for every woman, man and child in the electorate of Scullin. It is in the context of those figures that I grieve today for the future of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. Over the last few years I have often thought that one would grieve for the future of the PBS simply on the basis of the pressures that are on that scheme, including from the introduction of new and costly drugs and those arising from the inability of the government to see its way clear to supply the level of resources needed so that people in the community do not incur increasing levels of co-payments for those drugs.

speech.para: Any member that knows their electorate well would have had the same experience that I had in my local pharmacy of being in a queue behind a mother who, after taking the dispensed drugs to the counter to pay for them, realised that she could not afford the total cost because a couple of her kids were sick and there were two or three prescriptions that she had to purchase. This mother had to come to a decision about what she would forgo, whether it was filling a prescription for one child and not the other or forgoing something else in the weekly budget. These are crucial decisions that confront Australian families.

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Schemeâwhich for nearly a 50-year period has supplied drugs to Australian families, making them accessible on a cost-effective basisâhas been a very successful public policy. Yes, over the last decade or so governments of both persuasions have had to tinker with the scheme to ensure that we can still have drugs that produce a proper outcome for health issues listed and that we do so in an affordable way. As in so many other areas of public policy, a decision has been made that that will be done on a cost sharing basisâthat is, based on what the government put forward to support the scheme and what they think the community can put forward, with safety nets for those that are more disadvantaged or receiving benefits. The other thing that has been very important for the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, because of the price controls that we have in place and because of the way governments have administered the scheme, is that some of that cost has been shared by the pharmaceutical companies themselvesâbecause it is clear that they do not get the same prices in the Australian market as they can get overseas.

My grievance today concerning the future of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme is even greater because of the pressure that the US free trade agreement could potentially place on that scheme. In answer to a question today, the Minister for Health and Ageing talked about the free trade agreement being a once in a generation opportunityâthat we would now become part of a domestic economy with 300 million people, that we really needed to get there, and that the PBAC would continue to be the gatekeeper for the PBS.

Let us look at that large market of those 300 million people. If we think about what they have to pay for those drugs, that should start to ring alarm bells for anybody who wishes to look at the way this agreement might impact on Australian public policy. Take some of the more well-known drugs. For example, the wholesale price in Australia for Lipitor, which is for cholesterol, is $49.95, while the wholesale price in the USA is $89.50âa 79 per cent differential. For a drug like Losec, for stomach ulcers, the wholesale price in Australia is $39.12, while in America it is $102.66âa 162 per cent difference. There are a host of othersâfor example Ventolin, where the difference between the US price and the Australian price is 274 per cent.

Whilst there are assurances that the free trade agreement should not affect the way in which those pricing arrangements are made, it is part of continuing pressure by the pharmaceutical manufacturers to try to get through the PBS, to try to weaken the government's control over the pricing mechanism. I mentioned Losec. It contains omeprazole, which also has a generic drug form. One of the things about the free trade agreement is that the American manufacturers are concerned about the way in which we have been able to shape policies that give generic manufacturers a flying start so that they can get into the market very soon after patents expire.

This piece of policy to enable us to benefit from generic manufacturers was not developed overnight. Australia carefully went through a process which gave balances to the manufacturers who had the original patents in exchange for allowing a greater freedom towards the end of the patent life to allow these generic mechanisms. It started back in Labor years with the factor F scheme, which was about balancing the control we had through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme against the legitimate needs of the pharmaceutical manufacturers to have certainty when they were developing products for a domestic market and about encouraging those manufacturers to become exporters. But, at the end of the day, the fear we should have and the need for us to look closely at what the detail of this free trade agreement means for pharmaceuticals come from the fact that we are still a net importer of drugs.

In debate some time ago I quoted from an Industries Assistance Commission's report back in 1986. Of course, the Industries Assistance Commission were the precursor to the Productivity Commission. When they did their report into the pharmaceutical industry, they said:

quote.para: The pharmaceutical industry cannot be reviewed on the same basis as the majority of the Commission's industry specific reports. In most industry inquiries the primary focus is on tariffs or direct financial assistance to the industry. In this inquiry these issues are dominated by Government involvement in support of consumers, public health considerations and other social policy objectives.

speech.para: That in a nutshell is my concernâthat pharmaceuticals and the way in which we control them under our policy through the PBS has been tied up in the free trade agreement, which is by its title a trade agreement. There has been a lot of debate about what we have given away. There are attempts at assurances by senior ministers in this place at question time. I hope that I do not sound too churlish when I keep saying that the devil is still in the detail. There is an independent review mechanism that forms part of the 1,100-page document behind the FTA. But there is no detail of the way in which that review mechanism will operate. As was mentioned earlier in the discussions about this free trade agreement, Professor Stephen Duckett, who knows something about health economics, asked whether this is a third bite of the cherry for the pharmaceutical manufacturers.

There is talk about the process being transparent but then at the same time there is talk that it will continue to be behind closed doors. In opinion pieces there has been a lot of discussion about what the free trade agreement in toto should achieve. I understand that there will be pluses and minuses, but I believe that we have made a mistake in not protecting the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme from the free trade agreement. It is about Australia's national interests. It is about Australia's sovereignty. As John Hewson mentioned in the Financial Review last month, the Americans were in fact talking about Australia's sovereignty being significantly reduced or eliminated in areas such as the PBS. That is of great concern. When senior commentators like Alan Ramsey can come to conclusions like he did in an article on Saturday, that `most obvious is the trashing that would occur to our Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme'â (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI often reflect that my immediate family is a typical example of what makes Australia the nation that it is. I have an Italian father, who immigrated to Australia with his family as a refugee shortly after the Second World War. My mother, born in North Queensland, had an English father and an Australian mother. My wife, Astra, was born an American and now enjoys dual citizenship. My family is but one small example of the heritage of this great nation. It is a heritage that has delivered peace, stability and relatively good fortune to all Australians, whether they were born on our shores or chose Australia as their new home.

speech.para: Accompanying and accommodating our collective heritage is our uniquely developed Australian ethos. Commentators have coined a lexicon that embraces this ethos. Australian values shown in phrases such as `a fair go', `a fair crack of the whip' and `underdog supporters' are examples. As a cultural identity it is sometimes hard to define. However, it is quintessentially Australian to believe in a tolerant, open society. Australians have striven for a pluralist society for decades. It is a reflection of our past as a nation and an acceptance that Australians are very comfortable with cultural enclaves. Indeed, we hold a special place in our collective heart for the Chinatowns as well as for Lygon Street, Sunnybank, Footscray and Altona, to name only a few. As a nation, we have embraced yum cha, baklava, goulash and kebabs as alternatives to barbecued snags or meat pies.

For decades immigrants to Australia have recognised the promise of this countryâthe promise to provide a clean canvas for immigrants with the only consideration required being a commitment to being Australian. The best summary I could provide is encapsulated in the chorus of We Are Australian:

quote.para: We are one, but we are many;
And from all the lands on earth we come.
We share a dream, and sing with one voice,
I am, you are, we are Australian.

speech.para: Since those words were released to the Australian public, we have absorbed them. They best define our national insightâthe recognition that even though we may dress differently, eat different food or worship a different deity we are bound together by the dream of ensuring this nation remains a liberal democracy which provides reward for effort, a helping hand and, above all, a fair go.

My grievance today is that this commitment is being eroded. It is my observation that multicultural Australia is being hijacked by political correctness. The consequence of this hijacking has been the growing social divide we now witness occurring in our nation's cities. Slowly replacing our historical commitment to cultural diversity and an overarching uniformity of values are increasingly prevalent examples of the pursuit of value diversity. The social engineers of the political left reject historical Australia as fake multiculturalism. They view cultural diversity and value uniformity as only the half-measure. The Labor Party's commitment is to not only a culturally diverse but also a value diverse Australia.

Examples of the social upheaval caused through the adoption and promotion of a value diverse Australia include the frightening crime wave of pack-rapes that we have seen in Sydney's western suburbs. These were base crimes committed against Western women, perpetrated by criminals with a value set which dictates that Western girls are easy or are viewed as being sexually promiscuous. In the face of these crimes, the debate about cultural values in Australia became hot. Those on the political left sought to have the crime viewed as being no different to any other rape. Advocates for the left asserted that the moral turpitude of these crimes was no different to any other. The victims' factual accounts of racist slurs and race related verbal abuse highlighted that these crimes were not run-of-the-mill. These were crimes committed by individuals who showed no remorse for their actions. According to them, after all, the victims deserved it and were treated as they should have been.

The columnist Janet Albrechtsen appropriately and accurately classified these crimes and the value set that lay behind them as being a consequence of values diversity. She accurately highlighted the problems we see appearing in Australia because of this value diversity. Predictably, the politically correct pilloried her for daring to raise the issue. I expect certain elements to respond to this debate in a similar way. The current Leader of the Opposition, the member for Werriwa, used this chamber to publicly assail her, describing her in the most repugnant wayâespecially given the subject matterâas a `skanky ho'. The Labor Party and the political left may wish to see a world through the eyes of moral and cultural relativism. The promotion of values in which, for example, women are second-class citizens, Jews are morally corrupt or Western democracies are to be attacked and slain is offensive to the Australian character, to our heritage and, of course, to all Australians.

Recent comments by Australia's leading Muslim cleric, Sheikh Hilali, that the terrorist attacks of September 11 were God's work, intimations that he supported suicide bombers and support for a jihad against the West are all offensive. These comments, although disputed by the mufti as being translation errors, demonstrate a clear disdain for the pluralism from which Australia has grown and to which so many immigrants have contributed. Recent comments by the Australian Federation of Islamic Councils indicate recognition of the damage done to Australia's social fabric by such disgusting remarks. Of primary concern to me and to many of my constituents, however, is the knowledge that such views are at best often excused as being a cultural difference or at worst actively promoted and supported as some kind of ridiculous testament to our cultural maturity.

This nation is founded on cultural diversity and value uniformity. Australians, whatever their origin, recognise the strength of this bedrock and join together to assert this principle. It is a principle that should require of immigrants a demonstrated commitment. Our immigration policy favours those with English language skillsâthose who are seeking assimilation into Australia, witnessed not through their dress, their food or their god but through their values. The politically correct may have ensured that the term `assimilation' has become a profanity. However, it is not enough for immigrants to simply alter their geography. It is our values that must be adopted, not only our freedoms. Immigration policy should require a commitment to a pluralistic Australiaâan adherence to a `fair go'. Failure to demonstrate this commitment should result in expulsion.

The political left may, predictably, level the charge that I am the ghost of Enoch Powell. They are wrong. Enoch Powell was a racist. I revel in my family's history. I celebrate our nation's history and the great contribution virtually all immigrants have made and continue to make to Australia. I reject Powell's vision of nationhood. I do, however, find wisdom in one statement. Powell once argued that the nation is lived largely in the mind. This is the commitment that is sought. Australians are generous of spirit. We do not mind what your background is as long as you accept ours. Our nation should live in each of our minds through our commitment to garnering strength through cultural diversity, through testifying to our unity with the belief that all are equal and the belief in equality of opportunity and through being willing to give a hand-up. We are our own nation. Our cultural identity flows from our multicultural base; but let there be no mistake: it is not defined purely by it.

talk.start.para: âI rise today in the grievance debate to bring to the attention of the House the deplorable attitude of the Howard government in its lack of commitment to doing something about our citiesânot just our capital cities but also our provincial cities. In doing so, I remind the House that in 1996, on coming to government, the Howard government saw fit to abolish the highly successful and effective Building Better Cities program. Perhaps the member for Moncrieff, in raising issues about cities, should have some regard to the fact that his own government has no commitment to doing anything to overcome the problems that exist in our cities in the 21st century. I find that rather strange in such a highly urbanised society where more than 87 per cent of Australians live in our cities and suburbs. To me, it is unacceptable that the government can wash its hands of responsibility for urban development, but I dare say it is not surprising. The Prime Minister, as we appreciate, has no forward agenda and no original ideas or even simple requests about what the government might do in the rest of this term orâdare we think about itâpotentially after the re-election of the Howard government at the next election.

speech.para: Surely the 21st century could be about a debate on policies and where we go as a nation. In that context, I think it is also important that we dwell on a bit of history about our national commitment and willingness to accept some responsibility for urban development. That brings to mind the performance of the Whitlam government and its real, national commitment through the Department of Urban and Regional Development to do something about the planning and development of our cities. Unfortunately, that department was abolished by the Fraser conservative government on coming to office in 1975.

In comparison, I argue that Labor in government has recognised the vital need for a national strategy for our cities. Australia's last prime minister on the Labor side had a vision of urban development beyond the 1950sâwhich is the Howard government vision. With the assistance of Brian Howe, the then Prime Minister Paul Keating introduced a very successful Better Cities program. I note that Brian Howe was my predecessor in the seat of Batman. This program was so successful that it generated at least 60,000 jobs and supported an additional $3.7 billion worth of investment from the private sector and other levels of government. Infrastructure investments, as many suburbs and cities appreciate, helped to develop and renew key areas of our major cities, including the corridors connecting economic gateways to cities, population growth areas and areas of concentrated disadvantage. Some of these areas of concentrated disadvantage create the circumstances which lead to crime, which was touched on by the member for Moncrieff. Maybe it is time that we accepted it as the responsibility of the federal government to actually do something in our cities to overcome those disadvantages, which, in the end, contribute to issues on the crime front.

The Better Cities program was importantly underpinned by a paradigm that sought to improve prosperity, sustainability and `livability'. It featured, and rightfully so, area based strategies in capital cities and regional centres and promoted a concept of smart growth. In the 21st century, a nation such as Australia ought to be about smart growth. But the greatest achievement of the Better Cities program was its groundbreaking partnership approach between the federal, state, territory and local governments. Powerful and effective intergovernmental agreements between the Commonwealth and state and territory governments facilitated very effective urban development partnerships. Such partnerships are now impossible for the Commonwealth government to negotiate, because of their obsession with blaming the states for their own policy ineptitude. Unfortunately, all that good work by Labor in government came to a complete standstill in 1996.

Better Cities proved that effective partnerships with the states and territories provide fantastic growth and development outcomes and, in doing so, created a larger economic cake with associated employment implications. But unfortunately we find today a tired and divided government that is not able to achieve important reforms on the issue of urban development such as those the Keating government was able to achieve in the early 1990s and a Latham government will achieve after the next Commonwealth election.

We all must accept that our cities are major drivers of economic growthânot just our capital cities but also our provincial cities, such as Townsville, Ballarat, Bendigo and Broome, to name a few. At this time, some of these cities are also inefficient in their operation, in their use of energy and water and in the production of waste at every levelâresidential, commercial and industrial. They use a lot of energy and water and produce a lot of waste to create wealth. We cannot make Australia more sustainable unless we make our cities more sustainable. But the report cardâand it is an interesting oneâshows that the Howard government has failed to get involved. It has failed to work out solutions to the problems that confront Australia due to its high degree of urbanisation. It has failed to articulate any urban development policy and it has failed to develop a relationship with the state and territory governments that will address some of the problems facing our urban centres.

Of course, at the centre of policy development on this issue, as with all issues, is the issue of leadership. For the Commonwealth government to be involved in the sustainable urban development debate requires leadership. Whilst the Prime Minister remains in office and the business school of exploitation, in the form of the Deputy Prime Minister, continues in office, we can be guaranteed that we will see no leadership on the front of urban development and no willingness to work with state and local governments to overcome some of our urban problems in the capital and provincial cities.

Leadership will identify that sustainable cities require a significant reduction in greenhouse pollutionâsomething in which the Commonwealth government has a significant role to play. Leadership will identify urban planning and design as an important element in enhancing the sustainability of our cities. The Better Cities Program played a strong role in research and development of urban planning and design but its demise and the Howard government's anti-state and anti-territory stance has ended any Commonwealth role in the vital aspect of sustainable urban development. Leadership will also recognise the importance of congested roads, air pollution and overcrowded public transport.

Addressing these issues requires an all-of-govern-ment approach, a willingness to actually work together at the local, state and federal government levels to bring together a partnership to tackle these huge challenges. The problem is that the current government removes itself from this equation, this debate, and says the Commonwealth has no role to play in the public transport debate. This is another example of a lack of commitment by the Howard government to solving some of our problems of urban congestion in both provincial and capital cities.

I contend that urban public transport was a key part of the Better Cities approach under Labor. It was a mature, modern, honest acknowledgement that the Commonwealth government could not ignore the role of public transport in addressing the challenges of urban development. I therefore find it strange that the current government's proposal on AusLink rules out any participation by the Howard government in overcoming the challenges of urban development, in terms of the use of public transport and associated congestion. Surely a modern land transport plan for Australia in the 21st century would confront some of these challenges.

I remind the House that Labor not only had the Better Cities program but also put in place federal transport legislation that allowed a funding framework for urban transport infrastructure. The framework is there; you do not need AusLink or a new land transport plan. The Howard government, rather than using that framework, said it would be unconstitutional for it to be involved in public transport. That is complete and utter rubbish. It is a deliberate attempt by the Howard government to escape its responsibility for a better cities or liveable cities agenda. The legislation is still in place and unamended. The Minister for Transport and Regional Services should read the legislation, accept the Commonwealth's role and do something about it. In the face of all the evidence showing the benefits, both environmental and social, of an efficient public transport network, the will to do something should not be hard to muster, but the Howard government continues to pass the buck and deny responsibility.

The opposition understands the need for leadership on these issues and will not back away from its commitment to do something about it. Congestion is a cost to the economy, to business and to our environment. I believe that any government going to the next election should propose that one of the key issues for discussion is Commonwealth involvement in our capital and provincial cities. We need a plan that requires consultation between local, state and federal governments to do something on a Better Cities front. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âEight thousand, eight hundred and seventy-oneâaccording to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, that is how many Gladstone area jobs will be affected if an ALP government were to ratify the Kyoto protocol in its present form. Members know full well my feelings about Australia signing the Kyoto protocol and my absolute astonishment that the ALP is peddling this pap in the industrial city of Gladstone. Gladstone is a real boom town which draws people with the prospect of employment and an enviable lifestyle, but let us be clear on one thing: industry is the basis of this attraction and it is industry which will provide a future for the people of the Gladstone region. Gladstone's strengthâits very essenceâis its ability to provide cheap coal fired power, and that is what generates the types of industries which make it one of Queensland's fastest growing regions. It is also a major exporter of Central Queensland coal. This argument comes down to peopleâyoung Australians and their families seeking to provide a future for themselvesâyet the ALP seeks to deny these families their future.

speech.para: The opposition leader recently visited Gladstone on the pretence of going on a listening tour. I hope the local community was listening hard to him because the message was clear: the ALP will ratify the Kyoto treaty and will be the mastermind of industry closures and job losses. The Leader of the Opposition, when asked about his thoughts on signing the Kyoto protocol, was quoted in the Gladstone Observer on 28 February:

quote.para: We don't see it that way, we take climate change as an important issue ... it can actually be good for the national economy and that's the way we are approaching that issue.

speech.para: No facts, no evidence, no consideration of the impacts on jobs and no mention of the targets Australia is already meeting; just a self-serving grab for the Green vote in our southern capitals. One of his predecessors, the member for Brand, used a similar line when in Gladstone, saying that the ALP would sign the Kyoto protocol and negotiate special arrangements for Gladstone. We all know that international treaties and protocols do not work that way, and it is insulting that he should even suggest it. If anything, over time they tend to become tougher, not easier.

The ALP is so desperate to appeal to the common man that the rhetoric seems to change daily to suit the audience. Just last week, the Minister for the Environment and Heritage highlighted the Leader of the Opposition's two-faced approach to Kyoto. During the Cunningham by-election two years ago, the current Leader of the Opposition told voters in very definite terms, `You would be endorsing a Green candidate who wants to reduce greenhouse gases by 60 per cent, which would wipe out whole industries and cause the closure of BHP and the Illawarra.' In the same radio interview, he said that reducing greenhouse gases by 60 per cent was an extremist policyâa policy which, I might add, the ALP now promotes. So he believes Kyoto would be a bad thing for the people of the Illawarra but just fine for the 40,000 or so people in the greater Gladstone region. Clearly, the man does not know about achieving sustainable economic growth in regional areas.

As member for Hinkler, I have maintained a strong line on Kyoto. I will not allow Green populism to threaten Queensland Alumina Ltd, the world's largest alumina refinery, or weaken Boyne Smelters Ltd, our largest smelter and the third largest in the world; I will not let Queensland's largest cement manufacturer, QCL, waste away; and I will not say to Orica, the Gladstone Port Authority and NRG Gladstone Power Station, `Sorry, you might be efficient, but you can't compete on the world stage because of the Kyoto arrangements.' Would a responsible government turn its back on these job-generating industries without considering all possible options when it comes to fulfilling its environmental obligations? Clearly, the answer is no. A responsible government would balance its environmental duties with jobs growth, and that is what we are doing. I have a rather interesting ally in this debate: the Queensland Labor Premier, Peter Beattie. Mr Beattie is on the record saying that Kyoto would hurt Queensland. Challenged by a reporter who said, `That's what John Howard was arguing as well,' Mr Beattie replied, `Yeah, sure, it's true. I mean, I'm just telling the truth.' It is a great relief to see the Queensland Premier telling the truth.

The mayors of both the Gladstone and Calliope shires said as much in the opening comments of the Sustainability report for the Gladstone region, which was produced in 2001. Gladstone city mayor Peter Corones was concerned that the report be used to:

quote.para: ... address the growing need to manage our activities, to reduce the impact on the environment, enhance our present and future way of living and boost our economic viability.

speech.para: Calliope shire mayor George Creed noted:

quote.para: The Gladstone region is a key development area in Queensland's future and I believe it will show the rest of the world how to combine industrial development with environmental sustainability and quality of life.

speech.para: I believe that too.

Let me outline what the government has already achieved in terms of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. We have cut emissions from our own operations by 11.2 per cent since 1997-98, and we have set reduction targets in the same time frame as Kyoto. We have made significant inroads into meeting these targetsânamely, reaching levels equivalent to 108 per cent of 1990 levels. We have committed $1 billion to combating global warming since 1996, and we are the first country to establish a national greenhouse agency. We have also entered into a climate action partnership with the USAâI would like to see the ALP achieve that, especially given the way the Leader of the Opposition talks about the American Presidentâand we have commenced bilateral cooperation with Japan to address global warming issues.
The wisdom of that approach is backed by professor of international economics, Warwick McKibbin, who said in 2002:

quote.para: By any calculation, the sum of the future costs to Australia of ratifying Kyoto far outweigh the sum of the future costs of not ratifying. More importantly there is a great deal of uncertainty about the extent of these costs. Even our most optimistic assumptions support the government's decision about the long term costs of ratification.

speech.para: I will put it bluntly: ratifying Kyoto in its present form would tell investors that Australia is prepared to expose itself to costs that would not be faced by competing economies. In other words, Gladstone and Central Queensland would lose their edge. Our so-called emerging competitors would not have the same constraints. In short, we would be exporting jobs.

Similar words were used by Brian Fisher, the executive director of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, in a 2002 interview when he said that electricity costs in the $8 billion industry could jump by as much as 50 per cent by 2015, making aluminium production uncompetitive in comparison to countries with cheaper power supplies. He said:

quote.para: One can't imagine a company like Alcoa wanting to put a smelter into Australia if the energy price is one-third to one-half higher.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: If you look at Australia's aluminium industry, it's principally based on coal-fired power ... so any set of policies that were to drive up electricity charges would have a significant impact on aluminium producers' competitiveness.

speech.para: Aluminium and alumina are now Australia's fifth largest export commodity. They made up four per cent of Australia's total exports in 2002-03, valued at $4.1 billion, yet the Leader of the Opposition would put this at risk. As a side bar to this debate, I would like to highlight the duplicity of the Leader of the Opposition in his one-to-one meeting with Gladstone's mayor last month. Councillor Corones argued that a fast growing local government area should attract a percentage of any government funding given to large, employment-generating enterprises within that locality, with the idea that it would help local authorities provide public infrastructure and amenities. The Leader of the Opposition reportedly listened to his ideas but, consistent with having a different message for each audience, did not tell Councillor Corones that in 1995 he had said:

quote.para: Use should be made of the ... ABS census index of relative socioeconomic disadvantage for each local government area in Australia ... it is a great step forward for more equitable allocations of government resources.

speech.para: By his thinking Gladstone, with its average income of $36,146, would miss out on vital funding because it is well above the state average and the national average. I am no environmental vandal. I believe in reducing greenhouse emissions but we must also advance Australia's national interests.
