Now this duopoly has the gall to start a secret and underhand campaign by lobbying the state ministers responsible for state pharmacy regulations to change the rules so that they can have pharmacies in their supermarket chains. Mr Roger Corbett, the CEO of Woolworths, makes reference to a pharmacy without a pharmacist. That is an oxymoron. It is like having a surgery without a surgeon, a general practice without a general practitioner, a dental surgery without a dentist and Woolworths without fresh food. At present, we have a local pharmacy with a local pharmacist providing services to the local community. Under Woolworths's `100 pharmacies plan', you would have a national grocer with no pharmacist, providing no pharmacy services.

The local pharmacist is a fundamental aspect of the local Australian community. The dispensing of prescription medicines can be undertaken only by a pharmacist. On average, prescription dispensing accounts for some 60 per cent of pharmacy turnover. In addition, schedule 2 and schedule 3 products can only be sold with a pharmacist in attendance. If Woolworths is allowed a pharmacy within its supermarkets, there would be pressure on what products were stocked, how restricted stock could be marketed and what services could be provided. It is a clear warning that the service and standards the community enjoys with its community pharmacist will change dramatically under the Woolworths corporate pharmacist regime.

Coles Myer have a similar strategy. A quick analysis of documents leaked to me provides a useful insight into their thinking. Coles Myer research values the chemist goods market in 2002-03 at almost $A7.2 billion. What worries me most about this duopoly is that they are following US experiences where the role of the pharmacist is radically defined as:

quote.para: The pharmacist is becoming more of a counsellor to consumers, driving sales in many other categories at store level. The relationship between pharmacist and consumer can help bond the customer to the store.

speech.para: And the definition continues:

quote.para: Pharmacists can help promote the higher margin private label products by explaining to consumers the benefits of the store brand, its cost savings and the quality of the product.

speech.para: The duopoly plan begs the question: what services would a supermarket pharmacy provide? Supermarkets are most unlikely to provide all those extra services such as home medication reviews, asthma counselling, baby health services, diabetes programs or even home delivery. Allowing supermarkets to own pharmacies would reduce competition and lead to the same market dominance over pharmacy business that the major chains have over food.

talk.start.para: âEarlier this year I had the pleasure of attending the 65th anniversary celebrations of the Burleigh RSLâand what a celebration. A total of 111 people were in attendance for a great barbeque and some special speeches to remember and celebrate the 65 years of proud history of this wonderful club. In fact, the membership of this RSL has now reached 200âa great achievement and testimony to the friendship, loyalty and strong commitment this club has, particularly to those veterans who travel quite long distances along the coast to belong to this great subbranch.

speech.para: Since being elected in 1998, I have had a wonderful relationship with all the executive and members of the subbranch and I know I am welcome at any time just to drop in, when time permits, and on special occasions I am a welcome guest to help with the celebrations. At the 65th anniversary celebrations, I presented the club with two new Australian flags. They are always flown with pride by the club but, being so close to the beach, their life span is not as long as one would hope. Nevertheless, the boys know they only have to give the office a ring and a new flag will be delivered personally or sent on by my staff.

I would like to put on the record today a little bit about the history of the club. The Burleigh RSL received its charter on 3rd January 1939, but I understand the original ANZACs were hard at work in the Burleigh region many years before that event ever occurred. Anzac Day services were organised as far back as 1935. During the Second World War, the Burleigh ANZACs carried on the tradition of commemorating our war dead. Burleigh was a small seaside village and the club was struggling to survive towards the end of the 1940s, so they recruited some of the younger 2nd AIF boys to ensure the club's continuance. In 1953 the members, under the presidency of Mr Kevin Snee from the 2nd AIF, who is still a current member, acquired a state government grant of land and built a community hall on 6th Avenue, Burleigh, which was completed in 1956 and still stands today as a testament to those original ANZACs and to new Anzacs. During the 1950s and 1960s, the RSL hall was the hub of social activities in the local district. Up until the hall was built, the members met at the old Burleigh Heads Hotel on the esplanade. The new hall proved to be a great home and today serves its veteran community very well.

The current members deserve to be congratulated for the way in which the hall is managed and maintained. It is a delightful meeting placeâfull of memories, artefacts and a camaraderie that I have never felt in another club. It is well utilised by the members and local community organisations. In fact, it is used every day of the week. Membership has certainly seesawed over the years but, when the Australia Remembers program was introduced in 1994, there was renewed interest in the club and, in particular, in Anzac Day. With this program came a resurgence of membership and an Anzac Day service that is held every year at the memorial park, which is attended by over 5,000 local residents. My own participation each year is something very special to me and it is a wonderful sight each year to see the crowds grow with support from the local community.

The Anzac spirit is alive and well in Burleigh Heads, and the Burleigh subbranch makes a point of reaching out into the community through the local schools and involving both young and old in remembering our war veterans. I would like to say a special thank you to Mr Ken McNaught, Mr Chris Keating and Mr Ben Shuster, who have each made me feel very much part of the club over the years. These three gentlemen and all the club members deserve full credit for their work in our local community and their dedication and commitment to the Anzac spirit.

I would also tonight like to pay tribute to Robina Lions Club on the occasion of their 15th anniversary. Robina Lions is very special to me personally as I am a member of this particular club. Charter president Toula Singer compiled a special anniversary booklet celebrating this special milestone, and her continued support and encouragement of the club is certainly to be commended. In the few short years I have known this lady and her husband, Ray, I have never ceased to be amazed at the work they undertake in our local community. Robina Lions received its charter on 18 February 1989, with nine female and 15 male members. Over the years, membership has increased and decreased but the commitment to the Lions code of ethics and the strong belief and work that has gone into the local community and local projects has never dimmed. The commemoration booklet is a wonderful history of achievement for this small but hardworking club. As Toula herself said, compiling the booklet was a labour of love. Toula was the first female Lions Club president in Queenslandâshe was certainly a pioneer for women in Lions. Lions International has worldwide respect; it is a wonderful service organisation and one I am proud to be a member of, particularly of Robina Lions. I would like to take this opportunity of wishing all Robina Lions another rewarding and successful 15 years.

talk.start.para: âIn 1979, in both my home state of South Australia and nationally, courtesy of two conservative governments, egalitarianism and much of the fair go for all Australians disappeared from the lexicon of Australian politics. A common factor then and now is the current Prime Minister, John Winston Howard.
âNonsense!

âYou agree with me. In 1979 he was the Treasurer in the Fraser government. John Howard is a significant figure in the diminution of Australia as a fair-go society. A former leading dry Liberal MP, John Hyde, has lamented:

quote.para: âWith every day that passes, Howard looks more like Fraser.â

speech.para: The Prime Minister was Malcolm Fraser's Treasurer from 1977 to 1983. The Fraser government was known as one of the highest taxing and spending administrations by many traditional supporters. SnapâHoward repeats that today.

The Fraser government ended in tears and disarray. I somehow suspect that so too will the current government. Howard and Fraser of course were the stewards of the economic trifecta leading up to the 1983 federal election: 10 per cent interest rates, 10 per cent inflation and 10 per cent unemployment. The Prime Minister's recent attack on the lack of values in government schools was designed to drive a wedge between Labor and the non-government school systems. The Prime Minister's recent announcement of $362 million-plus to Catholic education appears to have more wedge than intrinsic worth as its motivation. I do not oppose public funding for private schools. The only provision is that it be nonpartisan and fair. If the current amount of dollars for private schools is justified, and I think it is, then public funds should be doubled. But the Prime Minister is partisan.

talk.start.para: âI warn the member for Sturt!

âHe hates `public' and that is the nub of the current problem. Even a cursory look at the Prime Minister's stewardship in his current position, and in his former life as federal Treasurer to the Fraser government, shows overwhelming and irrefutable evidence of his hatred for all things public.

speech.para: In 1977, when the current Prime Minister was federal Treasurer, the public school share of Commonwealth funding was around 63 per cent, with private schools 37 per cent. That is what a responsible non-partisan federal government would do today. If the federal government can ignore endowments, assets and fees, why does it take into account state government funding? Consistency was no attribute of the government between 1977 and 1983. Under Treasurer Howard's appalling stewardship, public education's share of Commonwealth funding fell from 63 per cent to 46 per cent from 1977 to 1983âa simply amazing kick in the guts for public education. And of course electoral cynicism was never far away.

After initially reducing funding for public education from 1977 to 1979 Howard actually increased funding back to its original 1977 level for the 1980 federal election. That was the first and only time the current Prime Minister was involved with increasing funding for public education. But, as I indicated before, it did not last. During the Hawke-Keating years the government funding for public education at least stabilised with the public-private share being 45-55. However, on resuming power in 1996, the Prime Minister was at it again, crucifying public education with no subtlety whatsoever. He has taken the 45-55 public-private ratio of funding education to 33-67 in just eight years. In other words, he has more than totally reversed the public and private share of education in this nation, from the 63 per cent public to 37 per cent private ratio in 1977âwhich is the nonpartisan correct ratioâto the 33 per cent public and 67 per cent private ratio now. It is not the right of a federal government to favour one system over the other; it should fund both on equitable terms. It should be fair and square, not partisan.

Although the Prime Minister appears to have gotten away with this amazing reversal, there will be a day of judgement for him and his government. There always is. The Prime Minister's obsession against anything public got him into huge difficulties when, as Treasurer post 1980, he lost total control of the economy, resulting in the trifecta of doom in 1983. But it is not only education; the Prime Minister's attitude is exactly the same with regard to health and communications. In 1987 the current Prime Minister said:

quote.para: Bulk-billing will not be permitted for anyone except pensioners and the disadvantaged. Doctors will be free to charge whatever fees they choose.

speech.para: In 1995 he turned that statement on its head when, for electoral purposes, only he stated:

quote.para: We're not going to contemplate altering the universality of Medicare. I mean, that is fundamental, and we're also going to keep bulkbilling ...

speech.para: He also said:

quote.para: We absolutely guarantee the retention of Medicare. We guarantee the retention of bulk-billing ...

speech.para: And pigs might fly.

Public health is in great difficulty in every state in Australia. There is no denying that situation. The wider electorate is sick of the blame game being played between the state and federal governments. Muhammed Ali made an interesting statement many years ago that sums up the current Prime Minister. He said that the man who views the world at 60 the same as he did at 30 has wasted 30 years of his life. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAt Federation 102 years ago, there was a very clear line drawn between the responsibilities of state and federal governments. In terms of roads, the federal government was given responsibility for the national highway which was to join the capital cities. The state governments were responsible for the major arterial roads between towns within the states. We have a population of 20 million and, of those people, only 10 million pay taxes. Those taxes pay for all of the infrastructure in this wide land. Compare us to Britain, where you have something like 130 taxpayers for every mile of national highway. In Australia, we have just 13.

speech.para: In the last week, the NRMA launched a campaign to have the national highway linking Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane upgraded to a four-lane highway. The NRMA urges that this is fair because around 80 per cent of Australia's population lives on the eastern seaboard between these three cities. Whilst this would be nice, it would cost tens of billions of dollars. It is for this reason that the only financially responsible way to do it is to stage the work. This work has to be prioritised across the entire network, including in areas like my electorate of Macarthur, which the Hume Highway runs through. That is what the Minister for Transport and Regional Services is doing and I fully support this approach.

Twenty years of population growth has seen the Macarthur electorate change from a few small suburbs to a satellite city in its own right, sprawled either side of the Hume Highway. For decades, the state government has approved new suburb after new suburb adjacent to the highway, with no regard for any employment base. Today, local jobs are scarce and this has forced more people from Macarthur to travel on the highway to work each day. Each day, the Hume Highway gives tens of thousands of commuters who live in my electorate access to their jobs in the inner city and the CBD of Sydney.

While I understand the need for a third lane to ease traffic congestion, people need to understand the real problem with this roadâthat is, it is congested during peak hours as everybody tries to get to and from work. Delays are common during the mornings and afternoons, when it can take up to two hours to get into the city. As a person who travels the road regularly, I know that you can make a trip from Campbelltown to North Sydney in 50 minutes outside of peak hours. It is hard to argue that we should spend $500 million in taxpayer funds installing an extra lane that will be used for only a few hours a day.

We need to cut to the heart of the issue. What we need to do is stop people having to leave the area to work. What we can do for those people who simply have to leave the area for work is to get them to leave the car at home. Once we have done that, if there is still a need for an extra lane, it will be time to start lobbying. But, until then, we need to take a longer term, strategic approach to fixing the real problem. By creating more local jobs, we will immediately get rid of cars from the Hume Highway. As the employment base grows, year after year, fewer and fewer people will need to travel on the highway. It might seem simplistic, but it cuts to the heart of the issue.

I refuse to sit by and continue to let people in my area spend up to four hours each day commuting to and from home unless they absolutely have to. We need to provide more local jobs as well as better services to those who absolutely have to commute. To do this, we need to improve our rail system so that it actually delivers an efficient, safe and clean service. When this happens, more and more people will use it and we can take more cars off the road. I do not blame the people of Macarthur for preferring to sit in the car for up to two hours when you consider that Bob Carr has run the train system into the ground. Anybody in this House representing a seat in Sydney is all too familiar with the headlines of the last few weeks: `Train chaos', `Carr drives commuters off the rails' and `Rail in crisis'. Train commuters now face daily rolling stoppages and hour-long delays due to the Labor government's mismanagement. Add this to the ever-increasing fares and you have a system that simply is not appealing.

I have started lobbying Bob Carr to improve the rail systemâto meet the current demand for better and more drivers on the system and to deal with other short-term issues like securityâso that rail commuters do not have to walk away from the system and take their cars to work. But he also needs to look at the long-term issue of getting more and more people onto the trains. He needs to introduce express trains from Campbelltownâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe issue I will address tonight is one that presents a choice for the Howard governmentâthat is, to back either corporate America or Australian small business. I have previously advised the House that a US company, Deckers Outdoors Corporation, is demanding, with the threat of legal action, that Australian manufacturers and distributors of ugh boots immediately cease and forever refrain from advertising, promoting, marketing, distributing and/or offering for sale their goods by reference to the word `ugh' or any other name incorporating the word `ugh' or its alternative spellings `ugg' and `ug'. Potentially hundreds of Australian small businesses and families now face hardship through loss of distribution outlets and sales, despite having traded using the word `ugh' for decades.

speech.para: The families whose livelihoods depend on the ugh boot industry do not expect the government to fight their fight for them or have the solution handed to them on a platter. These people are the kind who know that you rarely get something for nothing. They are not standing back and letting things happen to themâfar from it. They have united to form a national association called the Australian Sheepskin Association. The ASA have already established a fighting fund to cover the legal fees which have and will be incurred. My office has been in contact with the ASA. They have recently received their first legal bill for $12,000 and they expect another for $2,000 this week.

These people are real Aussie battlers who are not going to back down from a fight. The ASA is doing its part and it is about time this government weighed in with its support. Unfortunately, it looks like the government is quite happy to give way to the US corporation. I have written to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, the Hon. Ian Macfarlane, regarding this issue. I finally received a response last Wednesday from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, the member for Leichhardt. Prior to this letter, the closest I got to a reply was a media report that quoted a spokesperson for the minister, who said it was inappropriate to intervene in what was `a private legal matter'. The parliamentary secretary echoed this position.

Two matters that both he and the minister failed to address are as follows. Firstly, how and why did IP Australia allow the relevant generic terms to be trade marked in the first place? Secondly, what assistance packages, if any, may be available to the small businesses concerned? If the government is so ineffective in supporting this Aussie industry in these circumstances then, frankly, the fears held by some industries about the impact of the US-Australia free trade agreement on them are valid. Or is it the case with this government that it will support particular industries and/or and hang the rest?

What makes many Australians angry is that Deckers' actions are driven by profit, not principle. Deckers' share price was worth less than $US4 a year ago. They now trade at the $US26 mark. Net sales and net earnings for the most recent quarter increased by 39 per cent and 81 per cent respectively. For the full year, sales increased 22 per cent to $121 million. Net earnings rose 465 per cent to $9.2 million. Deckers' own web site states the growth was driven in large part by sales of the company's Ugg product line of sheepskin boots. Sales of the Ugg line in 2003 jumped 55 per cent from the previous year to total $37 million. It is worth noting that Deckers has been able to generate these profits while Australian companies have been trading using the word `ugh'. There is no reason to presumeâexcept perhaps for the vagaries of the fashion sceneâthat Deckers will not continue to make similar profits in the future. The issue is that they want to make much, much more while ugh boots are fashionable, at the cost of our own home-grown industry.

The government should not be prepared to have yet another Australian icon go the way of so many others before them. The production of ugh boots provides employment for thousands of Australian families. It is simply not right that a US company that wants to increase its profit margin by a few more million dollars can destroy their very livelihoods. While the Howard government seems quite happy to wash its hands of this matter, I will not. I will continue to work with constituents like Bruce and Bronwyn McDougall, whose business `Uggs-N-Rugs' is located in my electorate, to raise awareness and funds to keep `uggs' an Australian icon.

Finally, I would like to conclude by saying to the Minister for Industry, Trade and Resources that if he will not officially support this campaign I would encourage him to make a personal donation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak about the tangled web woven by the Labor Party in Victoria. Victorian communities are suffering as the Bracks government and their federal Labor representatives allow their union cousins to run roughshod over the employers, employees and people of Victoria. Because of their weak stance, local small business operators are left to foot the bill.

speech.para: Let us not understate the magnitude of this issue: Victoria is in turmoil and it is because of militant unions and a do-nothing state government. Last week, the federal Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations drew the House's attention to the Australian Services Union dispute and its impact within the electricity sector. It is all very well for Mr Bracks to come out and declare war on the unions. However, the war started long ago and is not being assisted by the federal ALP, and I might add that the war is on the verge of being lost.

I raise this question: who is running the state of Victoria? What sort of government allows the cutting of essential services from small business, and what sort of alternative federal government expects innocent, hardworking small business owners to cop the wrath of such dissidents? A headline in the Herald Sun newspaper claimed: `Union bans biting hard'. These bans are not just biting hard; they have gnawed and chewed at our state's industrial relations performance and they have caused the lay-off of workers and severe disruption to the customers of innocent employers.

All this is happening while federal Labor watches the destruction from the sidelines. No wonder this is happeningâafter all, according to the member for Rankin, the shadow IR minister, the Labor Party and the unions are in partnership once again. Let us look at who the ALP is in partnership with. Businesses in the East Burwood shopping centre were crippled two weeks ago when the Australian Services Union used militant and appalling tactics in an attempt to prove a point. Following a power blackout at the East Burwood shopping centre, workers from the electricity supply company attended the site to repair a fault. However, due to work bans, the workers were prevented from turning the power back on. In that time 32 small businesses, a Kmart and a Coles were forced onto a backup power supply. In the interim, businesses lost stock, including: the butcher and charcoal chicken shop, who lost about $4,000 each; the ice-cream shop, which saw $1,500 just melt away; and the fruit shop, which estimates a loss of about $5,000. They are small business operators.

This centre, which employs over 300 people, was left without power for over 24 hours. It took until the following afternoon for the state government to threaten the use of essential services powers. The state Minister for Energy, Industries and Resources, Theo Theophanous, should have done this the minute the ASU threat was made. He should have put his union affiliations aside for the sake of small business and the livelihood of Victorians. He should have forced the ASU to turn the power back on. Instead, we saw a government pussyfoot around an issue of vital importance.

The Bracks government are not the only ALP representatives to sit on their hands in the face of union strongarm tactics. The member for Chisholm, who is all too happy to speak on issues in my electorate, has been strangely silent on this dispute. That is little wonder either, with the affiliation of the member for Chisholm, Anna Burke, to the ASU obviously hampering her fulfillment of her duty to her constituents. Fortunately for these traders and the nearby residents, at the next election they will be part of the Deakin electorate. Their wellbeing will not be sacrificed in the name of union mateship. It really is a shame when old union loyalties take priority over responsible community representation. If the member for Chisholm and her Victorian colleagues in this House are willing to silently allow industrial action to cost small businesses in their electorates, what silence can we expect when it affects the broader national community? I would imagine it would be deafening silence.

It is not only the member for Chisholm who is chained to the interests of the ASU. Since 1996, this union has pumped over $1,565,000 into the coffers of the Labor Party. The members on the opposite side of this House, and the entire ALP organisation, are shackled to the interests of the union movement. We should not underestimate the danger. The stability of our economy is under threat if the federal ALP wins office at the next election. Not only would there be nine ALP union-controlled governments in Australia, but Labor would go down a dangerous path, as surmised in the Australian, which states:

quote.para: ... Labor ... intends to reregulate sections of the economy, including the labour market. Wrong way, go back ...

speech.para: It is clear that Victorian residents and businesses are suffering due to the unions' tightening noose around the necks of their state and federal Labor representatives. It is time that the members opposite rose to represent the majority of their constituents rather than servicing the ever-reducing minority that pay for their re-election campaigns. Labor will be bad for jobs, bad for workers, bad for business and bad for Australia.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 9.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
to move

interjection.para: (1) the viability of many small wineries is under threat;
(2) in a large part this threat is the result of the Howard Government's introduction of the Wine Equalisation Tax;
(3) the Government has consistently failed to heed the advice of the Winemakers' Federation of Australia of the threat the Wine Equalisation Tax poses to small wineries; and

(4) the Government has ignored the comments of its own Trebeck report into improving the viability of small wineries by failing to address the problems small wineries are experiencing with the Wine Equalisation Tax.

talk.start.para: to move:

interjection.para: (1) commends the Government for providing an additional 200,000 child care places since its election in 1996;

(2) calls on the Commonwealth to consider alternative and further solutions to the provision of child care for Australia's families including cooperative arrangements with state and local government; and
(3) encourages every family to adopt the Give a Mum a Day Off program whereby once a month other members of the family do all the daily chores.

talk.start.para: to move:

interjection.para: (1) recognises that the battle at the Eureka Stockade represents a turning point in Australia's development as a nation, especially in the right of people to have a say in how we are governed;
(2) notes that it is 149 years since this important battle took place;

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 10 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Is he aware of a media release from the Australian Toothfish Industry in which industry representatives claim that despite a recent meeting by the Commission for Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources (CCAMLR), ânothing has been achieved to secure the future of toothfish stocks to prevent or deter illegal operators from stealing Australian stocksâ.
(2) What action is he taking to address these concerns.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) Australia has led efforts to combat illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing in the Southern Ocean, including around Australia's Territory of Heard Island and the McDonald Islands. Australia has successfully pursued a number of measures in recent years, both within CCAMLR and bilaterally with other nations. Australia continues to work closely with the CCAMLR Secretariat and CCAMLR Members to ensure that measures to combat IUU fishing in which Australia has been instrumental (such as a trial centralised vessel monitoring system and the toothfish catch documentation scheme) go ahead successfully.

In addition, the Australian Government announced in December last year funding of $40 to $50 million to enhance the existing patrol program, including for the Australian Customs Service to lease an ice strengthened vessel which will carry a deck-mounted 0.50 calibre machine gun, an armed Customs boarding party and Australian fishery officers. This initiative is specifically to respond to IUU toothfish vessels in Australia's Heard Island and McDonald Islands EEZ.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice, on 10 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2272, how many of the 1700 former government, defence personnel and employees of licensees have deductions for superannuation made at a rate of 5% of their former salary under the provisions of sections 20, 21 and 21A of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (SRC Act).
(2) Are any monies deducted for superannuation purposes remitted to private superannuation funds on behalf of ex-officers under these provisions.

(3) How many of the 1700 former government employees, defence personnel and employees of licensees are deemed to earn 10% on the government funded proportion of their voluntary redundancy package under sections 21 and 21A of the SRC Act.
(4) Does the 5% superannuation deduction based on former salary accrue a benefit; if so, when is the benefit payable to the contributor.
(5) How many applications for act of grace payments made by former public servants for monies deducted under the superannuation formula have been refused and on what grounds.
(6) Is he willing to consider individual act of grace payments to former officers.
(7) In respect of the Department's review of the benefit entitlement provisions under the SRC Act, (a) when did the review commence, and (b) has it been finalised; if not, when will it be completed.
(8) Does the operation of the provisions of the SRC Act currently result in outcomes or consequences which were unintended when the legislation was originally enacted.
(9) Why were the changes currently being considered not included in legislative changes to section 21 in 2001.
(10) Is he aware that under the provisions of the SRC Act some ex-officers have been further penalised by a reduction of up to 66% of their spouse's Centrelink parenting allowance payment.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (2) No. The contribution is a `notional' deduction only. Its purpose is to ensure that a former employee does not receive a higher net payment than they would have received if they are still employed. Weekly incapacity payments for retired employees are reduced by the notional amount to maintain appropriate incentives for workers to return to work and minimise reliance on the social security scheme following the cessation of employment.
(4) The notional superannuation contribution is not an accrued benefit.

(5) There has been one formal application for an act of grace payment in relation to the superannuation formula in the previous 12 month period. This application was refused as there were no special circumstances that warranted an act of grace payment.
(6) The Government considers all applications for act of grace payments on a case-by-case basis. Acts of grace payments are made to redress inequities in special cases.
(7) The Department began its consideration of the notional superannuation contribution and related issues in July 2002. I am expecting the Department to report to me by mid-year.

(8) The intent of the SRC Act is that all employees injured at work should, from 45 weeks of injury and regardless of whether they retire, receive weekly incapacity payments at 70% of their pre-injury normal weekly earnings. This is intended to promote rehabilitation and return-to-work and minimise reliance on the social security system. The Review of the SRC Act is considering a range of issues including any consequences or outcomes which were unintended when the legislation was enacted.

(9) The issues surrounding the treatment of superannuation under the SRC Act did not come to light until after passage of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation (Other Legislative Amendments) Act 2001.

(10) The SRC Act provides income replacement for Commonwealth employees who retire as a result of their incapacity. It does not define eligibility for parenting allowance payment. Nonetheless the Government is concerned to ensure that the interaction between workers' compensation and social security payments results in fair and equitable treatment. Eligibility for parenting payment is strictly defined to ensure that benefits are distributed equitably, that appropriate incentives to work are maintained and that there is no double counting of benefits.
